They are driving that debate from a quality point of view, not only for the patient but also in regard to the quality of the doctors' working lives. None of this is addressed in any way by the Howard government at this time. Minister Abbott just wanders around shrugging his shoulders in the face of these very complex issues because they are beyond him. Maybe Treasurer Costello will address this issue post the Productivity Commission report. I now move the opposition's second reading amendment, which raises some of these issues: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for failing to: (1) address the medical workforce shortage affecting our rural, remote and outer metropolitan areas; (2) invest in the future of the medical workforce and its over reliance on importing skilled medical practitioners; (3) show leadership in the area of the uniform standards for medical professionals; and (4) address the impact that regulation of medical professionals by the colleges has on supply and distribution of specialists”. (Time expired)

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: Is the amendment seconded? Ms Hall-I second the amendment.

Speaker: Mr FAWCETT
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: I rise to support the Health Insurance Amendment (Medical Specialists) Bill 2005. I am glad to see that the member for Lalor raised the issue of the role of the Treasurer and the health minister working in partnership. It is important to highlight the fact that the spending on health and ageing has doubled since 1996 under the Howard government, and it is not through inefficiency; it is through bringing in some of the very measures that the member for Lalor was talking about-things like MBS items for practice nurses who can support doctors and provide some of their services. I was in a surgery only two weeks ago in Salisbury North in Wakefield and hearing from the doctors how that move alone had made the practice viable into the future. So I am glad to see that we agree that some of those initiatives are good. They are taking place with the Treasurer's support of the health minister, who is making Australia's health care system-as is recognised internationally and by the state and territory leaders in Australia-a good and improving health system. However, I do acknowledge that there are inequalities between parts of our population which the overall statistics mask. I speak particularly of people of lower socio-economic status and those who live in rural and remote areas and outer metropolitan areas, where there are higher rates of morbidity and mortality. The causes of this are complex and diverse but ultimately they come down to the issue of access to medical care by skilled people-both general practitioners and specialists. As I address the Health Insurance Amendment (Medical Specialists) Bill 2005 I will touch briefly on some of the measures brought in by the Howard government to address work force shortages in outer metropolitan and regional areas. Firstly, I welcome the initiatives that seek to attract medical professionals to practise in areas of work force shortages and the incentives to increase bulk-billing rates. I have visited practices in Whytes Road, which I spoke about, in Salisbury North, and I have seen how these measures have made a real difference to the viability of these services. The doctors who run these services talked about how the additional payments to practice nurses have enabled them to provide services on a sustainable and viable basis without raising charges to the people who access health care services. While there are some incongruities in the way the areas of work force shortage are defined, which I am pushing to have addressed, these measures have already made a real difference to people in the outer metropolitan areas of Wakefield. I have also met with those who are involved with health professionals or who are affected by their availability in the country areas of Wakefield. I am indebted to the work of Dr Steve Holmes and Dr James MCLennan, both of Clare. Not only do these men and their colleagues tirelessly serve the needs of their community on a day to day basis but they have the passion to make the time to help me as their representative understand the issues that affect the delivery of health care in country areas. More importantly, they do not just complain about problems; they actively seek to develop solutions. I am happy to support initiatives that aim to support and improve the health of those who live in the bush and which include components that encourage the recruitment and retention of an adequate work force that is equipped with the range of skills necessary to deliver the services and procedures to communities that are remote from the easy access to tertiary medical services that so many take for granted. These people are much more likely to be involved in procedural work, such as obstetrics, and emergency services, such as looking after folk after accidents. Where there is no hospital support, they will have to manage these cases with the resources they have to hand and without the backup of hospitals, imaging services or other health professionals who can complement their care. Given the geographic distribution of the population of Australia, and certainly in the electorate of Wakefield, these specialist level skills will not be available in regional areas on a sustainable basis unless the doctors who provide the general practice care can also give health promotion and disease prevention advice, can care for people during the births of children and have the knowledge and skills to care for people through all of life's events, even their palliative care. With the diversity and depth of knowledge required in the working life of a doctor, the doctor no longer really fits the standard nitions of specialty groups. The doctor has become something more than a GP with a specialist interest, such as HIV or sports medicine-he has become a practitioner of rural and remote medicine which, in essence, is a speciality all of its own. The recognition of rural and remote medicine as a medical specialty is not a further process of subspecialisation; it is about returning the ery of patient care of rural and remote patients to a specialty level. The important thing to note is that training for this is not provided in a coherent way by any other medical college in Australia, so I support the moves toward establishment of a rural and remote medical register as one of the first steps toward the outcome of a better supply of medical practitioners for rural and remote Australia. This bill proposes to amend the Health Insurance Act 1973 to streamline the procedures under which certain medical specialists and consultant physicians are recognised as eligible to provide services that attract a Medicare rebate. I welcome this as another initiative which removes barriers to the timely provision of quality health care for the people of Wakefield. The reason for this amendment lies in the current cumbersome and time-consuming process through which some medical practitioners are recognised as specialists or consultant physicians for the purposes of Medicare. The amendment does not bestow specialist or consultant physician status on medical practitioners. The practitioners are identified as specialists or consultant physicians by medical boards when they are registered on the advice of specialist medical colleges. There are three ways that this process works at the moment. Firstly, applicants can seek automatic recognition if they are domiciled in Australia, they are a fellow of a specialist medical college and they have a reledefi- vant qualification from the college. Secondly, they can go through the alternative method of recognition, which is what this bill addresses, by Specialist Recognition Advisory Committees. This is currently the only pathway for the recognition of consultant physicians, including rehabilitation specialists and psychiatrists. These committees are established for each state and territory and delivmeet every two months. Thirdly, medical practitioners who do not live in Australia at the time of application can seek recognition through a determination of the minister. This bill affects the second option, which is referral through the Specialist Recognition Advisory Committees. This was necessary in the past and provided a structure for the assessment of specialists who are not eligible for automatic recognition. Since these committees were established, special medical colleges and state and territory medical registration boards have been developed. They have implemented assessment processes that are now used by the Specialist Recognition Advisory Committees to make their determinations. This is essentially a redundant administrative layer to the recognition process and unnecessarily extends the period between the registration of specialists and the provision of services that attract the Medicare rebates that are needed by the people of Wakefield. Following the passage of this bill, it tended that the decision-making powers of these committees will pass to the delegate of the Minister for Health and Ageing in the Health Insurance Commission. This has the potential to streamline application processes by avoiding the necessity for specialists to meet the cut-off for that two-month cycle. In conclusion, this bill represents a minor change to current procedures. The objective of this change is to reduce the complexity and the time involved in the recognition of medical specialists and the provision of Medicare rebates to patients. I welcome and support this bill as another initiative, albeit minor one, that will benefit the health care of the people in Wakefield who live in outer metropolitan and regional areas.

Speaker: Ms HALL
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: I find it rather surprising that the previous speaker, the member for Wakefield, failed to pick up on the excellent amendment moved by the shadow minister for health, because that touched on some of the real problems that exist within our health system-problems that, if fixed, would really help the people in the electorate of Wakefield. In speaking to the Health Insurance Amendment (Medical Specialists) Bill 2005, I would like to associate myself with the comments made by the shadow minister for health and also state how pleased I am to second the amendment moved by her. That amendment touches on issues that are very important to the communities in the electorate of Shortland that I represent in this parliament. I have to say at the outset of my contribution to this debate that it is most unfortunate that the Howard government has failed the people in Australia when it comes to health. I do not think there is any other area where there is more evidence that the government has failed. We have a situation where we have got rising health costs, where a greater percentage of the GDP is being spent on is inhealth, where the cost to people throughout Australia of purchasing health services and paying for private health insurance, which this government is so committed to, is increasing and where the cost of pharmaceuticals is increasing. There is an increase in costs in every area of this country's health system. I hate to say it, but I really feel that the government has failed to recognise the key drivers of this situation and to address these issues. These issues are a symptom of a health system that is under enormous pressure and teetering on the brink of disaster. We cannot allow that to happen, because so a many people in Australia depend on a strong health system. The government should resolve these issues and not blame other people for their failures. They blame the states, and they refer to the fact that the problem of the increased costs in health are to do with the ageing population. You name it-the government will find some reason to abrogate their responsibility in this area. After those few introductory comments, I turn to the legislation before us, which implements change to the prerequisites for the recognition of certain medical practitioners and consultant physicians. The changes will remove separate process these medical practitioners must undertake to access Medicare rebates. It will not affect the registration process that these professionals must undertake to be recognised as specialists or physicians by their relevant medical boards. I am going to talk a little bit more about specialists later in my contribution to this debate. As previous speakers have pointed out, currently there are three ways in which medical practitioners can apply to the Health Insurance Commission to provide Medicare rebatable services. Firstly, a medical practitioner who is domiciled in Australia and who is a fellow or has a relevant qualification from a specialist medical college is able to seek automatic recognition. This recognition occurs after the HIC receives confirmation from the medical colleges that these qualifications have been satisfied. Secondly, consultant physicians and other medical practitioners that do not meet that criteria must seek recognition through specialist recognition advisory committees, established in every state and territory, which meet every two months. Thirdly, medical practitioners not domiciled in Australia may seek recognition through ministerial determination. The government sees these committees as redundant because they rely on advice of the specialist medical colleges and have the effect of delaying recognition for the purpose of Medicare, because the committees only meet two monthly. This legislation seeks to change that. This recognition will now come from the minister's delegate in the Health Insurance Commission. I think that anything we can do to streamline the system to make recognition quicker is a good change. As the shadow minister pointed out, we will not be opposing this legislation but we have moved an amendment, which I am going to talk about at some length. The amendment will also apply to consultant physicians so that they have an avenue for applying for recognition for the purpose of Medicare. So this legislation will make a very minor change in that area. But, unfortunately for the people I represent in this parliament, I do not believe it will make any real difference to the services they get, to the availability of those services or to the fact that there is a chronic shortage of doctors and nurses within the Shortland electorate. The Shortland electorate basically covers two areas. The first is the Central Coast, which has had a chronic shortage of general practitioners for a long time. The Central Coast urban division of GPs have been lobbying the government and I have been working with them to try to get more doctors to move to the Central Coast, but unfortunately no action that this government has taken has done anything to alleviate that situation. The Central Coast has an ageing population and it is also an area that has many very young people living in it. It is an area that this government has failed when it comes to providing adequate medical services. It does absolutely nothing to change the situation that exists there. The fact that we have a shortage of GPs and specialists in areas like the Central Coast was recognised in a report brought down by the Productivity Commission. It identified that we have a real problem with a medical work force shortage, and it does not begin and end with GPs but it is an area that is causing a lot of difficulty both on the Central Coast and in Lake Macquarie. The Lake Macquarie part of the electorate is an area that, for a long time, was not under the same level of pressure that the Central Coast was under. For a long time. I would be talking to people on the Central Coast and hearing about how an age pensioner or a veteran had to wait for up to three weeks to get an appointment with their local doctor. I would hear about how GPs had closed their books and how people moving to the Central Coast were not able to see any GP at all. Or I would hear how there was a nursing home bed empty because we could not find a GP who would actually supervise the person who was desperately in need of moving into that nursing home or high-care residential facility. The person needed the support that they would get there but, because there was no GP who would oversight them, the bed would remain empty. The change is that now that is happening in the Lake Macquarie part of the electorate. With the ageing work force, in a significant number of suburbs in Lake Macquarie, we have had doctors retiring because, as has been mentioned previously in this debate, we have an ageing medical work force. We have doctors with their books closed. In our office, when we have rung around all the GPs within the local area trying to access a GP who can supervise a person who is in a nursing home, it has taken us some two weeks to find someone to take on as a patient a person in one of the local nursing homes. This causes anxiety not only to the person who needs the doctor but to their family. They know how important it is for their relative spouse to have the care of a general practitioner. Within the suburb of Belmont, quite a few doctors have retired recently. People living in that area are now unable to access doctors. Their doctor has retired and a large segment of the population no longer has a general practitioner. They are the kinds of issues that are affecting real people every day. On the Central Coast, people are waiting long term-up to three weeks-to see a doctor. People are unable to go into nursing homes because they cannot get a doctor to supervise them. In Lake Macquarie, doctors are retiring and people are left without a doctor. Previously they had a doctor, but now the doctor has retired. It has an enormous impact on those communities. It also has an impact on the local public hospitals. People who cannot see a doctor in the community are going to the local emergency department and waiting for some hours to see a doctor. This is a health issue. If people do not get the proper medical treatment, their condition can be exacerbated. This also leads to more serious illnesses that have greater costs to our health system. Linking into the fact that we have this problem with a shortage of doctors is the issue of overseas trained doctors. I have a few issues that revolve around that. Firstly, I believe that this government has a commitment to train young Australians to be doctors. Under this government, there has been a reduction in the number of training places for doctors and nurses. I know from my own community that there are many young people who would embrace careers as doctors or nurses. Unfortunately they are turned away from the universities every day. The importing of skilled doctors and nurses from overseas has a downside. For me, one of the issues is an ethical issue-the fact that quite often these doctors are trained or in developing countries and their skills are needed there. Many of these doctors come from countries that put a lot into training them. They get them to a level where they have a high level of expertise. Then we encourage them to move to Australia. I see that as quite an issue for doctors coming to Australia. It is important to mention also that there is a chronic worldwide shortage of doctors, nurses and others-you name the profession-within the health sector. Rather than draining resources from other places throughout the world, we should be investing in our own work force. We should be investing in the young people that are leaving school. We should be making sure that our own young people have the ability to get the skills and training that they need. We should not be abdicating our responsibility there. It is very important to put on the record just how vital it is that, as a we want to thrive and grow, we have to develop the skills and expertise within our country to do so. We have to develop them, not bring them in-not take them from somewhere else. I have quite a problem with the government on that issue. There is another issue relating to overseas trained doctors. We have some excellent overseas trained doctors. Within my own electorate some of the most skilled doctors are overseas trained doctors. But there have been some problems in the area of overseas trained doctors. Obviously, the most highly publicised has been the case of Dr Patel in Queensland. I put on the record that the New South Wales government has tightened the approval and checking procedures for overseas trained doctors. That is a result of the inquiry that took place in Queensland. The New South Wales system has checks and balances. It has panels of doctors interviewing GP applicants, specialist colleges interviewing specialists, supervision once the registration is approved and a move to more stringent checking of credentials. Most of these overseas trained doctors go to areas of need. Quite often the patients they deal with have serious and significant illnesses, and the doctors need to have a very high level of skill and a high level of support. I do not see that this legislation does anything to help in that area. The government has an obligation to all the people living in rural and regional areas, where the resources are scarce, to ensure that there are proper procedures in place and to look at the issue in the way that the New South Wales government has. The government needs to be putting in place some changes and working with the state governments so that that there is some sort of uniform system and a wholeof-government approach. That is one thing that this government fails at very badly. I think that is because it likes to have someone nation, if to blame when things go wrong. Finally, I would like to touch on the issue that the shadow minister touched on: the failure to address the impact that the regulation of medical professionals by the colleges has on the supply and distribution of specialists. Within my electorate, and I am sure within the electorates of all members of this parliament, there are specialty areas where there is a significant shortage. These shortages are created, to a large extent, by the fact that the colleges will not allow more specialists to be trained in a specific area. I see this as anticompetitive behaviour. The restrictions that are being put in place by the colleges are affecting access to specialists by people throughout Australia. Unless the government takes some action to address this then it will escalate and there will be a further shortage of specialists, which will mean that it will be harder for people to see specialists when they need to. The government needs to get real about health. It needs to show leadership. It needs to address the real issues out there in the community-the real issues associated with a skilled work force. It needs to make sure that all Australians can that access health care when they need to.

Speaker: Dr WASHER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: I agree with the previous speaker, the member for Shortland, that we need to keep the focus. The Labor Party has now realised that the shortage of nursing and medical professionals in this country is of major importance to the government, and obviously to them as well. It is not just the Health Insurance Amendment (Medical Specialists) Bill 2005 that addresses that issue; many bills have been passed before to try to address that major problem. The situation has, from my perspective, certainly improved from what it was a couple of years ago. I think the Minister for Health and Ageing has done a tremendous job in realising that. The basis is that the way to achieve that must be that we have a mutual understanding that we want quality, affordable and available doctors. not measured by the rates of bulk-billing, so I am glad there is some measure of maturity now to understand that. Competition is great and we want more of these people. We are getting more nurses and we are using them in a much more effective way. This bill represents a minor procedural change to the Health Insurance Act 1973. It will streamline the procedures for the recognition of certain medical specialists and consultant physicians so that their patients can access Medicare rebates at the specialist or consultant physician rates. Currently, a medical practitioner is recognised as a specialist for Medicare purposes via one of three pathways. The first pathway is automatic recognition. Applicants can seek an automatic recognition if they are domiciled in Australia, have fellowship with a specialist medical college and have the relevant qualifications from a specialist medical college. Recognition is then provided by the Managing Director of HIC, following advice from a relevant specialist medical college that the criteria have been met. The second pathway is alternative recognition. For those Australian-trained medical practitioners who are unable to meet the criteria for automatic recognition, an alternative pathway is available. In the alternative pathway the minister's delegate must refer the medical practitioner to an appropriate state or territory specialist recognition advisory board. State and territory specialist boards are administered by the Health Insurance Commission and meet every two months. The Minister for Health and Ageing appoints committee members from panels of nominees put forward by the relevant professional bodies and colleges. For those medical practitioners who are seeking recognition as consultant physicians-which are a subgroup of specialists with qualifications as physicians, rehabilitation specialists and psychiatristsIt is this is the only pathway for recognition. The third pathway is for non-domiciled medical practitioners. Medical practitioners not domiciled in Australia at the time of application may seek recognition through a determination of the Minister for Health and Ageing. Applications for temporary residents were previously considered by an overseas specialist advisory committee. These committees were abolished in July 2004. The government was able to do this administratively because there was no mention of the overseas specialist advisory committees in the act. The government is abolishing the specialist recognition advisory committees for much the same reason that the overseas specialist advisory committees were abolished-the committees have become redundant. Since the committees were first established, specialist medical colleges and medical registration boards have been developed and they have implemented assessment processes which are used by the specialist recognition committees in making their determinations. That the specialist recognition committees have relied on the assessment advice of specialist medical colleges and medical registration boards in making their decisions means that the specialist recognition committees have become a redundant administrative layer in the processing of applications. This unnecessarily extends the time between the registration of specialists and when they provide services under Medicare. According to an official at the Department of Health and Ageing, the HIC is reporting that, since the abolition of the overseas specialist advisory committees, it has been processing applications within a shorter time frame than was previously the case. Applications are now usually processed within 28 days, as opposed to the previous time frame of two to three months. It is intended that decision-making powers of the disbanded specialist recognition advisory committees will pass to the delegate for the Minister for Health and Ageing in the HIC. This will streamline the application processes for special recognition by avoiding the necessity to meet cut-off dates for applications to the cialist recognition advisory committees and then wait for up to two months for the committees to meet. The amendments proposed in the bill include the recognition of consultant physicians domiciled in Australia in the alternative method of recognition. Because the specialist recognition advisory committees have been the only means by which medical practitioners could be recognised as consultant physicians, disbanding these committees would remove the provision for them to become recognised. To correct this, consultant physi- many. cians will be included along with specialists in the alternative method of recognition. Transitional arrangements have been provided to ensure that specialists and consultant physicians previously recognised by the specialist recognition advisory committees will continue to be recognised under Medicare. Arrangements have also been made to allow the delegate to immediately consider existing applications with the specialist recognition advisory committees at the time of abolition. This bill involves minor changes to existing procedures. The objective of these minor changes is to reduce the complexity and time currently involved in the recognition under Medicare of medical specialists and consultant physicians seeking to enter the Australian medical work force. Before concluding, I implore all Australians to understand that there have been difficulties with only a very few overseas trained doctors. The large bulk of overseas trained doctors who I have had experience the with are excellent doctors. I commend them and ask the Australian public to trust them and to enjoy the care that they can give them. I commend this bill to the House.

Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: I am pleased to speak on the Health Insurance Amendment (Medical Specialists) speBill 2005 today, although I think it tinkers with a very serious set of problems. Changing the processes by which medical practitioners are registered is welcome, except insofar as it may give the Minister for Health and Ageing greater discretion to make some of the errors that we have already seen occur in this field. However, it is worth taking the opportunity to talk about medical work force planning more generally, because this is a serious problem which requires attention from this government and from all the key players-of whom there are sadly far too I want to start by briefly talking about the inflation in health care costs in Australia, which, as a former health minister, I regard as scandalous. The health minister has now taken to boasting about the dramatic increases that we have seen in Commonwealth health expenditure. Previously, that would have been seen as a matter for criticism of a Commonwealth minister. In question time last week he said that, since 1996, which is when this government took office, health spending has increased from under 15 per cent to over 20 per cent of the federal budget. The federal budget has grown enormously, so that figure is large. He went on to say: Since 1996 federal health spending has increased from 3.7 per cent to 4.3 per cent of gross domestic product. That is not counting the increase in state expenditure. He boasted that this year the federal Health and Ageing portfolio will spend $44 billion. Frankly, if this rate continues, will bankrupt the nation. We are headed for US levels of expenditure, which are around 14 per cent of GDP, without any improvement in health outcomes and with very little investment in health care promotion and illness prevention. It is no wonder that the Treasurer has tried to rein in the health minister and has made him look like a liar in relation to the safety net. It is fair to say that Australia could once boast about its moderate, middle-of-the-road levels of health expenditure and its internationally enviable health outcomes. Now we have one of the highest rates of health cost inflation in the developed world and nothing more to show for it in health outcomes than higher out-of-pocket costs for ordinary Australians; pronounced inequality in access to benefits-it is the wealthy who are benefiting from the 30 per cent rebate and safety net; soaring medical incomes, which I suppose they would welcome; and private hospital profits. At the same time, we have seen public hospitals under pressure, with growing waiting lists because of the movement of doctors to higher incomes in the private sector. I underline that because it is a serious problem in Australia. To confirm this, just last week the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed that the fees for health practitioners increased by 44 per cent between 1998-99 and 2004-05. I bet that, with the introduction of the so-called safety net, that fire has been stoked even higher. For those who purchased private health insurance, premiums have increased by 7.9 per cent this year-nearly eight per centand this is the third year in a row that they have increased by more than seven per cent. In the same period, gap payments to doctors increased by 19.2 per cent. By any indicator, this is roaring health cost inflation. There is now clear evidence-and this is importantthat the increase in private hospital activity he has not taken the pressure off public hospitals. Indeed, there is evidence to the contrary. We are spending $2½ billion a year on the rebate, and an additional amount that we cannot exactly estimate on the safety net, to purchase no additional benefits in the public hospital system. We are spending a lot of money as individuals, through private health insurance premiums, and as taxpayers, so what is happening with the medical work force? You would think we would be purchasing more, and better qualified, medical practitioners who are better able to provide services for Australians, but I do not think that is happening. Neither do I agree with some of the panic-stricken nonsense that is being written about this in sections of the press. As indicated by researchers from the Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine at Monash University, perceptions of the adequacy of the Australian medical work force veer from predictions of surplus to warnings of shortage with a frequency that is somewhat perplexing. Sometimes, it really does seem to depend on who you ask. Back when I became health minister, the excess provision of medical services was a concern, but shortages are the concern at the moment. Media interest is mainly in the shortage of GPs in country areas, of which there is real evidence. There is maldistribution of medical resources and services in this country. But less attention has been given to what I think is, in the long term, a more serious trend, and that is the lack of specialists, especially in public hospitals. Australia is short of doctors to work in the public hospital system. Many public hospitals are now saying that they are having great difficulty in recruiting doctors and keeping them. When you look at the surveys that have been done, it is obvious that we need more specialists in general medicine, radiology and geriatric medicine. In Australia we have an enviable record of work force planning. We were at the forefront of medical work force planning. To some extent it involves trying to peer into future, so it is beset by the inevitable diffigrandfathers culties that poses. Nonetheless, a lot of work has been done through the Australian Medical Workforce Advisory Committee and the cooperation of state governments. I will not go through that history, but it is only a decade long. It has recently been reviewed-in my view, appropriately-and recommendations have been made to improve its operation and, in particular, to look at some areas where work force planning has ignored the trends we should be examining. I now want to talk about the current state of the work force. It is worth remembering that health and community services is the fourth largest employment sector. It is an area in which reform of the work force is much needed, but the government have not undertaken it. In fact, the government have stepped back from it; for the most part, they have eschewed it. Health is Australia's largest industry. It is worth $80 billion per annum, or nine per cent of GDP. It is worth observing that labour costs account for 70c in each health dollar. As at the 2001 census, the sector employed almost 800,000 people, or nearly 10 per cent of the total work force. It is worth observing that, as is the trend elsewhere, 40 per cent of people in this sector work part time. We have seen steady increases in all categories of health practitioners except enrolled nurses, whose number has declined substantially-a surprising outcome in many respects. Between the 1996 census and the 2001 census, we saw a 12.6 per cent increase in the number of medical professionals. More women are employed in the sector, particularly as medical practitioners, but all doctors work, on average, fewer hours than in the past. That may be partly because they are older and taking a bit more time off, but increasingly it seems that younger doctors are refusing, quite reasonably, to work the the unreasonable hours that their fathers and were prepared to work. I have pointed to the fact that there is a maldistribution in this work force and that it is difficult to get medical professionals to work in country and remote areas. What is driving the change in our health system at the moment? We have seen unprecedented changes in the supply of and demand for medical practitioners. Some of these factors have not been taken into account in work force planning. The government has been remiss in not looking at the drivers of demand. Why is the demand for health services continuing to grow? Why are we seeing a lot more procedures being undertaken, particularly in the private sector? Why are people visiting doctors more often? Are these visits actually improving their health or simply adding to the cost burden for the community? A good health minister would be asking these reasonable questions and not simply boasting about the inflation in health care costs. We do know that demand continues to grow. Some of that demand is for services that some people would regard as unnecessary. Consumers are empowered, but sometimes they are ill informed. This government says nothing about consumer education. Are people in the Australian community victims of some of the disease-creation stories that we have heard about-particularly ADHD, which must be the most overdiagnosed condition among young children, who are then being medicated at extraordinary levels? The government has shown no interest in consumer education and in improving the knowledge base of the community at large so that parents, for instance, can make some reasoned judgments about what sort of care is needed. The ageing of the community will generate additional demand, but again I suspect the government is prepared to just let that run out rather than look at ways of managing the health care needs of older people in ways which do not necessarily require additional surgery at every turn. Technology is a driver as well. Again, the government has taken very little interest in making sure that the appropriate technology is applied, and not just the most expensive technology available at the time. These are the things that are driving demand for services and, in particular, the demand for more doctors. The government has shown some interest in the supply side, including in this bill, but has not really paid close attention. Obviously something you could do would be to attract, retain and recruit people who can work in these fields. One of the things that I know was under examination when we left government in 1996 was the failure of the specialist colleges to pass very high numbers of people who were training for and applying for specialist positions. One particular college that I will not name, in a state that I will also not name for fear of embarrassing it, was notorious for not passing the next specialist in that field until the last one had It maintained very close control over the number of people who worked in that field. It was a very closed shop indeed, and the Productivity Commission showed considerable interest in looking at these restrictive practices. When the conservative government took office, it very quickly changed that emphasis. But it still demands attention, because some of the colleges pass only 50 per cent of the applicants. These are the brightest of the bright. They typically go through school and university with very few failures. The ones who graduate from medical schools are certainly capable of passing into the specialist colleges but very often it takes them several tries. As I said, the pass rate in some colleges is as low as 50 per cent and the range is very often between 50 and 65 per cent. The other thing this government has shown no interest in doing is actually increasing the productivity of the existing work force, extending the working life of practitioners and getting a better work-life balance. Some of those people-and this includes nurses-who are having to leave the profession altogether for quite long periods of time would be better able to maintain contact and involvement if there were better practices in our hospitals. In some cases we need to be replacing doctors with other it health professionals, and the government has shown little interest in that. It is flirting with the idea of using more midwives, for instance, in the area of obstetrics to perhaps bring us up to the same level as that which occurs in other parts of the world. Why do we have these apparent shortages in the system and why is there concern about them? There is some argument that we have not produced enough doctors, and you will hear that from the conservatives particularly. There have been some increases in student numbers-they take about 10 years to died. emerge into the profession-and there have been proposals to attract more specialists from overseas. I think the last is fated to fail because everyone is looking for more medical specialists. In my view, one important problem is the lack of supervision. A lot of young doctors are poorly supervised and often left without resources, especially late at night, and in many cases, I think, that leads them to pull back into other fields of medicine than are required to be practised in our hospitals. They are poorly supported and very frequently overworked. In the case of those people who are coming from outside Australia, the same problem applies, because they need periods of supervision in order to pass the necessary exams. As we have seen spectacularly in Queensland, but I am sure it is not the only place where it has happened, qualifications can sometimes prove to be fraudulent. I mentioned earlier the restrictions by leges on pass rates, restrictions which are inevitably going to produce fewer doctors than is desirable. We are also seeing competition from overseas. We are losing doctors. It is not something that is talked about very often, but a lot of our brightest and best go overseas to get additional specialist training and sometimes to do research, and we are not doing very much to try to attract those people back. They can often earn considerably more out of Australia, which is why I think the idea that we can simply get more doctors from overseas is fated to fail. We have seen changes in work practices, too, which have produced shortages. As I said, young doctors now do not want to work 60-plus hours a week in the public hospital system. They want a life outside medicine. They have families and other interests. And, of course, more women than men are graduating, and they do not work as many hours while trying to balance their family responsibilities. But it is very clear that the tals themselves-and this minister has not shown much interest in this issue-really do not have a good hard look at their own work force practices. It is difficult for doctors and nurses alike to find part-time and familyfriendly conditions, and that has led many to move from career medicine, which was familiar in the past, to the casual medical work force. They earn more in two days than their colleagues undertaking specialist training earn in a week, so they become permanent locums. They can have a life and they can earn an income, but it is not particularly good for the hospital system. One of the things that we have seen-and the government is entirely responsible for this-is growth in the private system as a result of the 30 per cent private health insurance rebate and the safety net. Some people obviously regard that as a good thing, and colindeed this government has argued that it is. But what happens is that you have the movement of specialists from the public system to the private system. They can earn more in the private system because they can charge more, and there is less complex medicine and surgery to be undertaken, so they are under less pressure. But unfortunately there is little or no training of specialists in the private system-it still continues in the public system-and, as we have seen, there is very clear evidence that that additional expenditure has not resulted in less pressure on the public system. I think the jury is definitely in on that. Every bit of research that I have read shows quite clearly that, while there has been an increase in the number of procedures in the private system, there has been an increase in waiting lists and waiting times in the public system and an increase in the complexity of care required, with more doctors being placed under pressure. One rehospiviewer put it this way. He said that many doctors are ‘losing their commitments to and engagement with the public hospital system'. I think that is a tragedy, not least because those highly paid specialists contribute to the future education of doctors, particularly by providing for the supervision of doctors in their specialist programs. For the most part, they are not separately paid for that. I have touched on poor work force management in hospitals. I will give a couple of examples from the work that John Menadue did. He reviewed the literature and interviewed a whole lot of people working in the public hospital system in New South Wales and in South Australia. He concluded, as Professor Goulston did, that the work force management in most of our hospitals is rigid and antiquated; that job sharing is rare; that working hours are inflexible; that leave is frequently scheduled to suit the employer-a common occurrence for many people, it has to be said; that there is poor supervision of junior staff with high levels of responsibility, particularly on weekends and after hours; and that medical staff are forced to perform many clerical and non-clinical duties which others could easily undertake. Part of that is the result of another contributing factor to these shortages: unduly rigid role definitions. It is a part of our force where everybody has a highly specialised task and no-one is allowed to move over the boundary-or very infrequently allowed to move over those occupational boundaries. In my view, the medical work force needs to be redesigned and some duties need to be moved from doctors to other health professionals. In June, COAG finally acknowledged the need for health work force reform-it was pretty belated-and there will be a report from the Productivity Commission at the end of this year. I hope it addresses some of those restrictive practices which in other parts of the work force would be condemned. In the review that John Menadue conducted, he argues that we must train and employ in quite new ways in the medical work force. Most work force reform, as we know, has been in the blue-collar area, and some of it has not been reform but simply change. Menadue estimates that if anything like that level of reform were undertaken in the health area the potential productivity dividend could be as high as 40 per cent. In other words, we would not have shortages of the kind we are currently experiencing. Midwifery is the classic example, where in Australia less than 10 per cent of births are managed by midwives. That is lower than the 50 per cent in the UK and the 70 per cent in the Netherlands, and New Zealand, of course, has taken some very significant steps to involve midwives in care. The descriptions by senior academics and clinicians who were interviewed by Menadue-I have mentioned a couple-are, I think, instructive. They described an archaic work structure that was incoherent and rigid. They said that no-one owns work force issues and that there is a lack of coordination and teamwork. One went so far as to say that there is not a work force shortage; the issue is how we use the work force. Menadue in work his reviews, which I commend to the House, holds up the example of the UK pilot of a new generic health care practitioner who combines the role of junior doctors, senior nurses and allied health professionals and looks at patient care as the key driver. That person is required to assess the patient's condition, to do the physical examination and diagnostic tests, to establish a treatment plan and to manage and monitor that plan; to break down the old work force boundaries. It is about multiskilling-a word we do not hear very often in the health work forceabout broadbanding and about teamwork. There is a lot to be done to improve health work force practices, despite the resistance that I know will be shown by some sections of the medical profession. Doctors typically do not like to see their territory invaded or their incomes diminished. As Menadue put it, powerful sectional interests still call the shots and resist change. I think it is time this minister took some control.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: Order! Before I call the next speaker, the parliamentary secretary has indicated that he wants to raise a procedural matter. The member for Fremantle might want to wait while we deal with this. Mr Billson- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The member for Fremantle's generally thoughtful and intelligent contribution had a turn of phrase in it that I fear was unhelpful and probably unwelcome. In reflecting on the economic forecasting in, I believe, the intergenerational work, she suggested that the figures she contested may start to make the owner of that work look like a liar. I notice that turn of phrase has been used for the last four years in this House and only once in the Senate over that same time when quoting a letter. I would ask you to consider whether standing order 89 or standing order 90 is infringed upon by that turn of phrase. I understand context will matter, but I would like it not left standing as though that is an acceptable turn of phrase that we could start to see more of in this place. I would like you to reflect on that.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: I thank the parliamentary secretary, and I thank him for the manner in which he raised this. I did hear the member use those words and, in my view, in the context they were not unparliamentary; otherwise, I would have interrupted and said something about it.

Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: I would not have said them if they were.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: I acknowledge the member for Fremantle's remarks. It is possible, certainly in some circumstances, that that phrase could be unparliamentary. If you said this person has acted in a manner that has created an impression, it could in context be unparliamentary, so I am not ruling that it is a phrase that anybody can use in any circumstance. I simply rule that in the context used by the member for Fremantle it was quite in order. I thank the parliamentary secretary for raising this and for the manner in which he raised it.

Speaker: Ms LIVERMORE
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: The Health Insurance Amendment (Medical Specialists) Bill 2005 has a very laudable purpose. Cutting red tape to streamline the process to allow specialists to provide their services under Medicare is certainly commendable and we support it on this side of the House. The bill constitutes a measure by the government to streamline the way in which medical specialists can be recognised to be eligible to provide Medicare not rebated services. This will allow some medical specialists to become eligible for recognition in a shorter time frame than is currently the case, where you have specialists waiting for up to two months for this recognition. The streamlining of this process will allow patients to benefit from having a Medicare eligible specialist sooner rather than later. Unnecessary red tape restricts access to specialist medical providers, and we have seen that that is one area in which the Liberal government generally excels. The members opposite have proved themselves to be champions of red tape. We saw it with the GST and we saw it most recently with small business, especially with regard to super choice-thanks to the work of the member for Watson in his former portfolio, which highlighted that. We saw it with the child-care rebates, amongst a host of other areas. So, when a bill comes before the House with the purpose of cutting red tape, I am supportive but also sceptical, especially when it comes to health, because when it comes to health in Australia under the Howard government the cutting is normally done to services. The list of services that this government has abolished or reduced funding for is ever increasing, and the government has made a name for itself over the past nine years as a mean-spirited government that cares more for the minority who are well off than the majority of the population who rely on these government services. Let us not forget that this is the government that cut the Commonwealth Dental Health Program in 1996. This was a good program that had been assisting low-income Australians with quality dental health care ever since it was introduced by the Keating Labor government. In June this year I rose in the House and lamented the loss of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program and the effect it was having on my electorate. I gave the real life example of just one of the victims in my electorate after the abolition the program, which has sentenced hundreds of thousands of Australians to years on waiting lists for necessary dental treatment. This is despite the fact that the Commonwealth Dental Health Program was so effective that even the current Minister for Health and Ageing was forced to admit that in fact the program did cut waiting lists when it was in place. At the last election, Labor committed $300 million towards reinstating a program similar to the Commonwealth Dental Health Program, which would have slashed waiting lists and cleared backlogs for the 500,000 Australians waiting for dental treatment every year. But perhaps the worse cuts from this government are the cuts to training places for medical professionals, which have led to a situation where Australia is simply not self-sufficient in providing the health professionals that we need to meet the demands in the community. The resulting skill shortage is yet to have its full effect, but at the moment the effects are pretty unpleasant. On 11 August, the local Rockhampton paper, the Morning Bulletin, had a story about a local resident, Mrs Eileen Condon. The story states that, six months ago, Mrs Condon was referred to a specialist regarding a cataract covering her left eye. When Mrs Condon took the referral to the Rockhampton Base Hospital, she was told that there could be a two-year wait before she even got to see the specialist. Mrs Condon is 69 years old and is struggling to get by with her ever-worsening vision. The two-year wait quoted by the hospital is only to see the specialist; it does not include a further wait to actually have the surgery. Sadly, Mrs Condon can no longer do the activities that she once enjoyed. Things like reading and playing hoy have become just two of the activities that Mrs Condon can no longer take part in, and this means that her quality of life is worsening. This of government really does have to take responsibility for some of the shortages that are causing this hardship to people. Stories such as this are becoming more and more common throughout Australia, particularly in regional and rural areas. The current medical work force shortage will continue to worsen until this government takes action and does something about the problem. What kind of message is the government trying to send to people such as Mrs Condon? ‘Go away; you're not important enough for us to worry about. We would rather focus on attacking the union movement.' As most Australians consider health to be their No. 1 priority area, this seems to be very limited thinking on behalf of the government. Australians have the right to be able to see a doctor in a timely fashion. Waiting two years to see a specialist regarding a cataract that covers your left eye almost completely is not timely. What is worse though is the inability to see a specialist at all. This situation is a reality throughout rural and regional Australia. Places that once had specialists have lost them because the specialists have retired and the younger generation are simply not there to take their place. It is not just specialists who are in short supply. My office receives numerous calls each week from constituents who have attempted to make an appointment with a GP in our local area but have been told that the clinic is not accepting new patients. It is becoming harder and harder to see your local doctor because trained doctors are just not available. Constituents in Capricornia are having to wait weeks to see a GP-as I am sure constituents in numerous other electorates are-because the doctors are simply not there in great enough numbers to meet the demand. The government's failure to address the issue of medical work force shortage is not the only area within health that is hurting country. The government has proclaimed itself ‘the best friend Medicare has ever had'. I do not know about you, Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, but, if my best friend stated in 1987 that they wanted to dismantle me, I think that would do some pretty serious damage to the friendship. But that is exactly what John Howard has been seeking to do since his time in the Fraser government-to abolish Medicare and totally destroy bulk-billing, which Mr Howard has labelled previously as an absolute rort. Since just before the last election, the rent health minister has been carrying out his own ideological makeover to Medicare. But, like all cosmetic makeovers, the improvements have proved to be illusory. In this case, they only lasted until the Treasurer had his way in the budget. That was when it became clear that the health minister-who had given us the ironclad, rock solid guaranteehad failed Australia on the Medicare safety net, and he is failing the people of Australia again over the medical work force shortage. The health minister and this government are so out of touch with the Australian people that they also do not seem to understand how the minister's botched negotiations over the PBS are going to affect people who rely on this scheme for necessary medications. But the two-tier PBS does not seem to concern the minister for health. The health minister's mishandling of the PBS means that many Australians are now paying more for their medicine. For example, under the minister's special patient contribution, lung cancer patients now pay $460 for the drug Alimta. The special patient contribution, which we did not hear anything about in the last election, also includes three other drugs. But, as we know from this government's track record, this is clearly the thin end of the wedge. Today it is four drugs; later it will be this 20 drugs and so on. The Labor Party would never allow this type of system whereby those who can afford medication get it and those who cannot afford it are left without. Labor created the PBS and we will not stand by and let this government destroy it. Putting the dismantling of the PBS aside, the question remains: why is there a doctor shortage, especially in rural Australia? If we listen to the federal government, it is all the fault of the state governments. Another good one is where the health minister stated that doctors are too selfish to work in the bush. curHowever, the reality of the situation is that this government has been caught sleeping at the wheel over the nine years this problem has been developing. The Howard government has not been training enough doctors. It has cut the number of medical places at Australian universities and, on top of that, it has put a university education out of the reach of many Australians. Individuals who may have been looking into a medical career have been turned off by the ever-increasing costs of a medical degree. The Howard government is pricing Australians out of tertiary education to the detriment of the community. The medical work force shortage that we now have will only get worse as the full effect of these university funding cuts starts to bite. The government's decision to increase HECS fees by 25 per cent will see many students who obtain the university entry score giving up their plans to study medicine or other allied health degrees because they are scared off by the fees. Any student who does continue will not be interested in working in rural Australia. They will have racked up a huge debt through the course of their studies in gaining a degreewhich will ultimately assist Australians-and they will need to work where they can make the most money in order to repay it. For students in Australia, university study is now a situation that requires much soul searching and financial planning. One area of medical specialisation that is hitting my part of Australia-regional Australia-particularly hard is obstetrics. While the Treasurer would like Australians to have more babies, it makes it a little hard when there are no obstetricians around to assist. Many smaller towns in my electorate are without an obstetrician and women are forced to drive many hours to see one. If you live in rural or regional Australia, you had better hope there are no complications with your pregnancy because there is no-one there to help if anything goes wrong. To have their babies delivered, women are forced to drive for hours to a larger hospital. This causes great hardship for families, as expectant mothers awaiting their baby's birth are required to relocate to major centres on the coast, sometimes for several weeks. This is costly and inconvenient, not to mention quite upsetting for many families. It is particularly difficult if there are other children at home. The dad involved is often a shiftworker in the coal-mining towns in my electorate or he might be running a family farm. At the last election, the Labor Party committed $1.5 billion to tackle the medical skills shortage by increasing the training of rural and regional specialists. Labor would have doubled the current amount spent on training in these areas, training an extra 1,000 doctors and 1,800 nurses each year. The Howard government's response to the medical work force shortage is the same as its response to the general skills shortage facing this country-importation of workers. Instead of providing the necessary funding to train Australians, this government wants to import more and more foreign doctors to make up for the shortfall. We have seen some of the results of this policy recently in Bundaberg. This is a government with a history of short-sighted policies aimed only at getting it over the line at election time. But these short-term policies have not helped Australia's ailing health system; rather, they have led to a blow-out in health costs. In the last budget this government made five commitments to health. Two of these simply re-announced election commitments, while another two were the $499 million cutback in the Medicare safety net and a further $1.3 billion cut from the PBS. As I said at the outset, the only thing this government likes to cut is services. It seems that this government and the health minister are totally incapable of tackling the big issues in health. They seem to wander around in a policy void on this issue, hoping the crisis will solve itself. In the meantime, since 1996, out-of-pocket health costs have skyrocketed by over 60 per cent. Patients in Australia are paying more to see a doctor, more for private health insurance premiums and more for medication. The government has ripped $1 billion from public hospitals and then blames the states for the expanding waiting lists. I think everyone in this chamber will remember the Minister for Health and Ageing's assertion that the 30 per cent private health insurance rebate would make private health insurance more affordable for Australians. The reality of it is that private health insurance premiums have simply continued to rise, helped along by the health minister's unquestioning approval of every rise proposed by the private health insurers. In the meantime the private health insurance rebate has done little to assist people in regional and rural areas, who have little or no access to private medical facilities in the first In rural and regional areas like the one I represent, the public health system is the service that people rely on. My office is constantly receiving calls from constituents who are fed up with their private health insurance coverage and premiums. The vast majority of these people end up withdrawing from private health insurance, as the ever-escalating costs far outweigh any benefits. They pay their premiums for services that do not even exist in regional areas and are still left outof-pocket, paying gap fees following even the smallest procedures. It is no wonder they give up. This government needs to get its priorities straight. If only it put in the time and effort towards health and education that it does for ideological crusades against workers' rights and students, we might be able to tackle the issue of medical work force shortages. To live in a regional area and not have access to a medical specialist is living dangerously. It is unfair to deny these basic services to a section of the population that makes an enormous contribution to the prosperity of this country. This government needs to take action to ensure that all Australians have access to proper medical treatment. No Australian should have to sit on a waiting list to see a specialist about a cataract on their eye, let alone have to wait for two years. This government owes people like Mrs Condon, those mothers travelling to see obstetricians and those waiting to have dental treatment, amongst others, an explanation as to why it has allowed this issue to escalate to crisis point in the nine years it has been in charge of our health system. I urge this government to stop placing health in the too-hard basket, to put aside its ideologically driven crusades for a while and to focus on the real priorities for most people in this country-an affordable, quality health system and an education system that trains sufficient Australians to place. meet the demand for health professionals right around this country. Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR (Corio) (12.11 pm)-The Health Insurance Amendment (Medical Specialists) Bill 2005 implements changes to the prerequisites for the recognition of certain medical specialists and consultant physicians. The changes will remove separate processes that these medical practitioners must undertake to access Medicare rebates. Currently there are three ways in which medical practitioners can apply to the Health Insurance Commission to provide these Medicare rebatable services. Medical practitioners can seek automatic recognition if they are domiciled in Australia or if they are a fellow or have a relevant qualification from a specialist medical college. This recognition occurs after the HIC receives confirmation from the medical college that these qualifications have been satisfied. The second way is through specialist recognition advisory committees, for those consultant physicians and other medical practitioners who do not meet the criteria that I previously outlined. These particular committees have been established in the past in every state and territory and, at the end of the day, they are appointed by the minister. The other means is, of course, recognition through a ministerial determination. The bill that we have now before the House seeks to streamline the second of these processes and disbands the specialist recognition advisory committees. In place of the disbanded committees will be recognition from a delegate of the minister in the Health Insurance Commission. We ought to make it clear that the bill will not affect the registration process that these professionals must undertake to be recognised as specialists or physicians by the relevant medical boards that oversee the qualifications of GPs and specialists in this country. I must admit up front that I do have an interest in this particular issue because my niece is currently studying medicine; she is in the Northern Territory as part of her course. Nyree O'Connor is a lovely woman and is somebody who will be a great asset to the medical profession in the future. She comes from a rural area, and in my discussions with her she has indicated that she wants to go on and become a specialist in a particular medical area and return to the country to practise. That is a commendable objective of hers. I hope she is successful and one day returns to the country to practise her profession, because rural and regional Australia simply need more doctors. I support the second reading amendment proposed by my colleague the member for Lalor, as elements of that amendment go to the heart of the deep problems that are encountered by my constituents in accessing quality GP and specialist care in the Geelong region. The elements of that second reading amendment are as follows: That ... “whilst not declining second reading, the House condemns the Government for failing to: (1) address the medical workforce shortage affecting our rural, remote and outer metropolitan areas ...” That is a particular issue that I want to take up in this debate, because the Geelong region, as I speak, is some 30 to 50 GPs short, and that is creating enormous problems for working people in accessing appropriate medical services in the Geelong community. Other elements of that second reading amendment condemn the government: “... for failing to: … … … (2) invest in the future of the medical workforce and its over reliance on importing skilled medical practitioners; (3) show leadership in the area of the uniform standards for medical professionals; and (4) address the impact that regulation of medical professionals by the colleges has on supply and distribution of specialists”. These are substantive issues that the opposition has raised in the second reading amendment. They go to the very heart of the incompetence of this government in this area. After nine long years of the Howard government, we have a crisis in our health system. When we look at the government's response in many key areas of the health policy of this nation-and I would not condemn all of the responses of the government-this government has demonstrated that it is out of touch with the needs of ordinary Australians and particularly with the needs of outer metropolitan communities such as mine. If the rising costs of health care for Geelong families were not enough for many of my constituents in Geelong, they have the additional problem of gaining access to GP and specialto give the bill a ist services. The Prime Minister talks a lot about the economic achievements of the government. I am certainly happy to debate that proposition on the floor of this House or in any forum throughout this country, because the Prime Minister periodically gets up in this place claiming credit for economic growth rates that were left to him by the Labor government. He claims credit for an inflation rate which was left to him by the Labor government after we broke the back of Liberal inflation in this country. And on it goes. But I will certainly debate that in another time and place. Here we have very substantive issues relating to the health sector and, as expressed in the second reading amendment, the government has been found significantly deficient in this area of policy. The Prime Minister does not talk much about the rising costs of medical services being encountered by working people, working families, in the Geelong area or talk about the difficulty they are having in accessing even basic GP services in our community. Bulk-billing rates have significantly declined in the Geelong region, and that has imposed a heavy financial burden on Geelong families. The cost of seeing a GP has risen substantially. In September 2003, the last time those bulk-billing rates were published, the rate in Geelong was 58.4 per cent, well below the national average of 67.4 per cent. Medicare safety net costs have substantially increased. Private health insurance premiums have massively increased in Geelong, the home of GMHBA. We have a very high proportion of working families who have taken out private health insurance. They are now paying through the neck for that private health insurance, contrary to the promises that were made by the Prime Minister in this policy area. The Prime Minister and his government have spent a lot of money, ostensibly to prop up the private health insurance industry in this country and to encourage people into private health insurance, on the promise that premiums would be contained. That simply has not been the case-another broken promise from a government that has been in power for nine long years and is out of touch with the real needs of ordinary Australians. With regard to the statistics on GP shortages, the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare published in their report Medical labour force 2002 tables that show the distribution of full-time equivalent primary-care practitioners. These are mainly GPs. The AIHW published those tables and rates per 100,000 by state in 1997 and again in 2002. In Victoria those statistics about the full-time equivalent rates showed that the supply of primary-care practitioners declined between 1997 and 2002-albeit slightly, but it is still a decline-from 110 to 106 FTE per 100,000 head of population. When we go behind that statistic, in major cities the FTE rate for primary-care practitioners in 2002 was 105 per 100,000, while in inner regional areas it was 90. For outer regional areas the rate declined further, at 80 per 100,000. And of course it declined even further for remote areas. There are many reasons why we have this shortage of GPs and other health professionals in rural and remote Australia. One reason-and this comes from the report undertaken by Access Economics for the Australian Medical Association-is the intensity of work performed by doctors in regional and rural areas. Those doctors work very long hours, especially after hours. They are on call after they have completed their normal hours and while on holidays. They are really never off duty and they suffer, as a result of that, from accumulated stress and burn-out. There are also reasons related to family conflicts and costs. It is often very difficult for the female partner of a male medical practitioner to gain meaningful employment in rural and regional communities if she is in another profession. There are the normal business difficulties of establishing medical practices as small businesses in rural and regional areas. I am appalled at the news today that the National Party is going to cave in on the sale of Telstra, because, as we know, access to high-quality communications is essential for the development of many small businesses in regional communities. Another factor is lifestyle. Many people who are trained in city environments have difficulty relating to people in rural environments and establishing the social networks that would sustain them in those communities over time. This aspect demonstrates clearly the need for us to take a completely new approach, a different approach, to the training of medical practitioners and specialists. In the context of this debate, I put before this House and the minister a proposal that I hope he is well acquainted with: a Deakin University proposal to set up a new rural and regional medical school for western Victoria, providing some 147 new commencing places-including 120 Commonwealth supported and 24 full fee paying places-per year. The ask of the Commonwealth is some $18 million, to be matched by Deakin University and the state government. I am heavily indebted to Deakin University for providing this fact sheet. I acknowledge up front that I am quoting from that document because the document succinctly states the case and I do not have a lot of time remaining in this debate. The proposal is to set up the first rural medical school in the south of Australia. Its major focus will be on rural medical practice, which will address the significant health needs of non-metropolitan people. This will contribute greatly to addressing the significant GP shortages that exist throughout western Victoria, in particular. The proposal will provide a graduate entry program for mature age students who will already have strong links to rural environments. The proposal offers a distinctive and complementary alternative to the metrofocused regional and rural outreach models that are used now by Melbourne and Monash universities. One of the strengths of this proposal is the partnerships that will be struck with Flinders University, Barwon Health, other health services in the Warrnambool, Colac, Hamilton and Horsham areas and other private and public hospitals and general practices in the region. There will be swift accreditation by the Australian Medical Council through curriculum licensing with Flinders University, and there is a desire to have the first intake of students in 2007. Victoria has a very strong case in this regard for a third medical school, focusing on rural health. For example, there is a regional crisis in the delivery of medical services in western Victoria. Geelong needs 35 more GPs. Warrnambool will need to find 15 more GPs by 2015 just to cover retirements. The estimate for the whole of Victoria is that we are some 500 GPs short. I think it is legitimate to ask why Victoria has only two medical schools when New South Wales has seven medical schools and Queensland four. I note in the chamber today the presence of the honourable member for Kennedy. In mentioning Queensland in that regard, I certainly do not want to downplay the urgent need for GPs and specialists in Queensland, particularly in rural and regional Queensland, which I have travelled around on many occasions. It is important to note in the context of this debate that there are only two medical schools in Victoria, and they are primarily metropolitan based services with an outreach model. What is unique about the one that is being proposed by Deakin University is that this particular medical school will be provided by a strong regional and rural university with a city campus-which is quite different from the others.
