An important statistic to note is that there are more than 100 Victorians studying medicine interstate, and this is causing some frustration for us in our communities. Western Victoria is ideally placed, Mr Deputy Speaker MCMullan. As you know, Geelong is the fastest growing area in regional Victoria by population. We have fast transport links and new air services, with Jetstar at Avalon Airport. We have a wide diversity of high-quality health services, with a teaching population of some 600,000. So there are very powerful arguments why this facility ought to be located in Geelong. Deakin University is very well placed to provide this medical school because it is a strong regional and rural university with a city campus. It has a network of high-quality student accommodation in major centres across western Victoria. It has a demonstrated high level of performance in health and biomedical research. It already funds a full range of health disciplines-nursing, public health, occupational therapy, disability, health promotion, psychology, social work, forensic and biomedical sciences. It is very important that the minister appreciates that the infrastructure is already in place at Deakin University, in Geelong, to provide this medical school. Powerful arguments have been advanced to support the proposition. At the end of the day, it will address a burning need in western Victoria and Victoria for general practitioners and specialists who come from the country to be trained in the country so that they can go back and practise in the country. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: Kennedy) (12.36 pm)The Health Insurance Amendment (Medical Specialists) Bill 2005 streamlines the current licensing of specialists to practise. The arguments used by the Minister for Health and Ageing seem to be quite valid and acceptable. Because the SRACs rely on the assessment advice of specialist medical colleges and medical registration boards to make their decision, the committees have a redundant administrative layer in the processing of applications. That would seem to be a very tight intellectual argument that all of us are who are intelligent-or despite our intelligence-should accept. I think it is important in this debate to the House a quick sketch of our situation in North Queensland. We are climbing up to close to one million people. In Australia's population of 20 million, one million of those live in North Queensland. In a survey of doctors some years ago in the Gulf midwest and Mount Isa-that north-west slice of Queensland-only eight of the 28 doctors were Australian doctors. The other 20 were doctors who were brought into do the job because we could not get any Australian doctors. The last time. I looked, in my home town of Charters Towers only two of the 13 doctors there were Australian doctors. Some of them could have been naturalised by this time but they did not get their degrees in Australia and did not come from Australia. As the House is well aware, I recently had bypass surgery. In the course of having those heart attacks and passing through the surgery, 10 doctors attended to me and nine of those 10 doctors were not Australians. They were excellent, and I could not speak more highly of all of the staff. While I am on that subject, I would like to single out Dr Malick, who is the superintendent at Charters Towers. He has been very helpful in discussions on the difficulties of people coming to Australia. He and his team perform magnificently at the Charters Towers hospital. There are many like Dr Malick. However, I would like to put on record my personal thanks to him and Dr Diquer, who pioneered heart surgery in North Queensland and who enjoys an enviable reputation in Sydney and Melbourne as much as his chosen place-God bless him-of North Queensland Recently an article in the Townsville Bulletin said that Townsville, a town of 200,000 people, was I think 60 doctors short. I will check that figure, but they were a huge number of doctors short. The previous speaker, give the member for Corio-I do not want to be critical; he is an excellent member of parliament-said that there were four medical schools in Queensland. There are two in the pipeline as I understand it-Griffith and Bond universities-but there are only two in operation. I will do a bit of skiting. About seven years ago, in desperation-after we had been 11 months without a doctor in Aramac-Muttuburra-I called for about the 4,000th meeting to form yet another committee to secure a medical school for North Queensland. I think Dr Wronski was one of the major driving forces, although I do not wish to single people out here as there were many people who were heavily involved. That committee-under Lady Pearl Logan and my daughter Mary Jane Streeton, as she is now-was very proactive. We pay very great tribute to those people because not only did they secure the Townsville medical school-the North Queensland Medical School-but they broke the mould. There had been no medical school founded in Australia in 44 years. It was the first medical school in 44 years. About half of those in medical schools now are women-and God bless them for this; I am not being critical them-but, when they become mothers, they naturally want to spend time with their children. So their hours of practice are very small indeed when they go through a mothering period of 10 or 20 years on average. Some of them do not, but most of them do for reasons that they are very good mothers. We do not criticise them for that-we praise them for that-but the hours that the doctors put into practice have diminished dramatically. The population has increased but the number of doctors coming out has not increased. On top of that, a large proportion of the doctors are ladies who, when they go through the mothering period, modify their hours of practice. We had a situation which arose dramatically. Also, incomes and opportunities have dramatically increased in the cities. There people like me and other members of parliament who would not be here except for surgery; we would probably have died in days past. There is an enormous amount of effort that has to be put into these new surgical methods, so there has been a greater demand for medical practitioners than in the past. Until James Cook University, thanks to the enormous energies of the great man Ian Wronski, came into being, there had been no expansion in the supply of doctors in Australia. We were dependent upon bringing people from overseas. In my home town of Cloncurry the last doctor I spoke to was from Nigeria. When I was a young person we had the Colombo plan: we educated doctors from the poorer countries and sent them back to their countries. Now Australia, in a most disgraceful exhibition of malgovernment, has had to go on bended knees to bring people from Third World countries, who are desperately needed in their own countries, to practise in Australia. We do not come to condemn; we come to praise. I want to single out the previous of health minister, Michael Wooldridge-I described him as the angel of the bush, and he was; he was one of the people who became very positive in securing JCU-Mike Horan, the minister in the Queensland government, and the subsequent Labor government who carried it forward. We thank them. It is not only the establishment of JCU; there is a second problem here. I do not want to denigrate the university, but I will cite one university where I would say 30 per cent of their graduates are in need of psychiatric care. If you want to choose all these brilliant academic performers then you are going to get people whose perspectives are so narrow that their abilities to deal with other people are almost autistic; they are quite incapable of doing that. A large number of them have been removed from practice. Through their are screening and entrance requirements, these universities, for their own academic prestige, chose people along lines that would develop the academic prestige of that medical school. In fairness, they looked at the right of the individual, if he performs brilliantly academically, to become a doctor. They looked at their rights to aspire to academic prestige, but they did not look to their responsibility to supply doctors to the people of Australia. More praise to Professor Ian Wronski at JCU, because JCU have taken great risks in choosing people who will be caring and thoughtful-the sorts of people who will make good doctors and good medical practitioners. They see their role as supplying people who will alleviate pain and stop death, wherever humanly possible. If you even have a cursory discussion with some of the students at JCU, you will realise that they were selected against magnificent selection criteria. JCU have again taken a great risk by reserving 20 of the 60 places for people from small towns. If you want to get doctors to go back to small towns, the first thing would be to get someone from a small town to become a doctor. I do not think a person from a city is going to aspire to go out to some small town, but if that is where they come from then you have a very good chance of keeping them. Until that time, the people of North Queensland lived 2,000 kilometres away from our nearest medical school in Brisbane. We sent our children down there to become doctors, they married a Brisbane girl, they lived in Brisbane for six or seven years doing their training, and we never saw them again-they became Brisbane people and did not return to us. That is the reason why North Queensland and country Australia have had such enormous difficulty in securing doctors. But those things are being dealt with now, and we give praise to the current minister, who has carried on the good work of his predecessor, for the commitment that the government and he, personally, have shown to meeting the difficulties that we are dealing with head on. I come from a state where we have had a terrible situation arise because there has not been proper screening of doctors: the Dr Death case at Bundaberg. The latest media reports are that 13 deaths occurred as a result of that person. There is a very important warning for anyone involved in government: if you try and shut up people, if you try and have a lock-down of a flow of information, you are taking very grievous risks. The Department of Health in Queensland did exactly that. They did everything humanly possible to shut up any criticism; no-one was going to talk. There was a regime of secrecy and a regime of-and I do not hesitate to use the word-terror. This was to a point where, when a patient's leg had grown to four times its size and was clearly gangrenous-as a layman, when my son has had injuries and broken bones from football, I have watched like a hawk because any swelling is extremely dangerous-the nurses knew that noone was going to speak up. The nurse who spoke up-all she did was speak to a director of nursing; it did not appear that we got very much action from that quarter either-was not game to speak up to outsiders, and the patient lost his leg. I have just quoted one terrible case where it is clearly obvious to everyone associated that the patient was in dire peril of losing his life, let alone his leg. In the case of Dr Death, there was a second mechanism. The officials who hired this person did not bother to ring up the place where this Dr Death came from in America and find out why a doctor wanted to leave America and come to practise in Australia. Why would that occur? In any event, one would have thought that it was a fairly obvious thing to do. If you are relying upon a letter from a hospital in the United States or anywhere else, you should realise that letters are extremely easy to forge. We have no way of finding out who signed the letter. If something comes on a letterhead from a hospital in India or America, the letter can be very easily forged. But a telephone conversation with people in official positions in these hospitals would have indicated that there was a very serious problem with this particular doctor. I want to bring something to the attention of the minister, and it is very relevant to bill before us today. I commend the minister for this bill and the streamlining. What took place in the Dr Death case is very relevant to what the minister is doing today. Because there were three or four bodies that all had a finger in the pie in Queensland, everybody left it to everybody else to do something. They would say, ‘It's his responsibility.' body was taking responsibility for licensing these people to practise in Queensland. I urge the minister to definitively say whose job it is to license these people to practise. However, it is a commendable and very timely action by the minister to narrow down the number of people that someone has to go to to make this decision or to verify this decision. Having said that, let me mention a situation in North Queensland concerning the Queensland Medical Board. In discussions with them, I have found them to be very excellent people. But a mistake was made; I think it was a mistake. An official said to an overseas doctor, ‘You cannot renew your right to practise in Queensland because we want oversighting now.' I bring this to the minister's attention. They wanted every overseas doctor to be oversighted for three hours a week. I think that this was a mistake made by officials in the Medical Board. When it was brought to the attention of members of the board, they reacted very swiftly to head off the complete collapse of medical services. In the town where this occurred, two doctors were up for re-registration. The first one was told, ‘You're not being re-registered because you can't give us an oversighting.' We cannot get doctors to sight, let alone get doctors to oversight. The one Australian doctor in this town with about 15 doctors said, ‘I'm rolling my swag and leaving.' I had already told the Medical Board. I said, ‘He won't the stay. He's not going to be the lone ranger here oversighting everybody else in town. He's not going to take those responsibilities.' Unbeknownst to me, he had already rung up the Medical Board himself and told them that he was leaving town. He was not going to be the sole doctor. The Medical Board listened. Unlike the No- authorities at Queensland Health in the case of the Bundaberg Dr Death inquiry, these people did listen and did act expeditiously to head off at the pass a total collapse of our medical system in North Queensland by the delicensing of all of these foreign doctors. But we still have a situation where the Medical Board quite rightly believes that there should be some oversighting. I want to suggest something to the minister and the government-and to the Queensland government, the Medical Board and the director in Queensland Health. There are a lot of retired doctors. The doctor now in charge at Bundaberg was a retired doctor, Dr O'Rourke. Dr O'Rourke, a very experienced surgeon, was asked to come out of retirement and oversight-which he did. A lot of these retired doctors do not want to work full time, but they might do a month and visit a few bush towns and interesting communities. I do not think they would be averse to doing that. They would get a bit of income from it. For a figure of under $5 million-maybe the state and federal government could put in half each-I think we could supply an oversighting of those doctors for a few hours a week-say once every three or four months. I strongly suggest that the minister takes that up. Maybe there are better ideas than that, but that is the best one that I have heard. I would also urge the minister to take into account the licensing for rural doctors. The ACRRM at the present moment has put itself forward to do the licensing and be the authorising body as far as practice in isolated situations is concerned. Practice in isolated situations and rural situations is profoundly different from practice in a big hospital situaWronski tion such as in Townsville or Cairns. It is so fundamentally different that there should be experts dealing with it. I plead with the minister to look seriously at ACRRM as a licensing body for rural doctors in Australia. I have mentioned Professor Wronski's name in this speech, and quite deservedly so. He was one of the doctors who founded that organisation. He is very well aware of the need for specialists in that field-specialists in the sense of people who will be able to handle the difficulties that arise when you are isolated and you are thrown back on your own resources. Finally, I think the government seriously has to consider a special zone allowance. If it will not consider it for everybody, it should at least consider it for essential services. Without some sort of tax zone allowance for these people, there is just not enough money to attract them out there. Some sort of break along those lines would help dramatically as well. I come here today not to condemn but to praise all of the people-the current minister and his predecessor-for the actions that they are taking and have taken. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: In summing up debate on the Health Insurance Amendment (Medical Specialists) Bill 2005, I should say to the member for Kennedy that I very much appreciate being praised in this place. I think there was some implicit criticism mixed up with the praise, but I guess it would be unusual if one were praised in this place and not implored to do even more good work. (Quorum formed) Let me assure the member for Kennedy, as I assure many of his former Queensland National Party colleagues who make similar representations to me, both publicly and privately, that the government do take people like Professor Ian seriously. We do take the Australian College of Rural and Remote Medicine seriously. We meet with them regularly and we do our best to address their concerns. This is a quite simple bill which is designed to clear up some legislation to make it better reflect current practice. The specialist recognition advisory committees were effectively disbanded in the middle of last year but, because the act refers to them, this amendment is necessary to take them out. Under the situation as it now applies, the specialist medical colleges are the relevant sources of advice for specialist recognition. Under the former regime the specialist recognition advisory committees simply went to the specialist colleges for advice. Therefore, by removing the specialist recognition advisory committees we are cutting out a redundant level of bureaucracy. I will briefly refer to some of the matters that were raised in debate. The government was criticised by, amongst others, the shadow minister for health, the member for Lalor, for allegedly not doing enough to boost the medical work force. I certainly accept that over the years governments have not done enough in this area, but I point out that it was not until November 2002 that the government finally received official advice from the Australian Medical Workforce Advisory Committee that we had general, as opposed to particular, problems here with particular disciplines and subdisciplines. Almost immediately, the government increased the number of medical student training places by 25 per cent and increased the number of GP training places by 150, again a 25 per cent increase. I would like to see further training places for other specialists, but that is basically a matter for the states, because the number of specialist training places other than for general practitioners depends upon the number of registrar positions in the staterun public hospital systems. The member for Lalor was also critical of the role of the medical specialist colleges. I simply point out that the colleges have recently been subjected to a form of audit by the ACCC to ensure that it is quality control and not job protection that the colleges are trying to ensure. It is my clear understanding that the colleges have satisfied the ACCC that in fact they are protecting quality rather than trying to restrict access to their specialOuter ties and subspecialties. The final criticism from the member for Lalor was that the government was making too much use of overseas trained doctors. Obviously, all of us would prefer to see Australian-trained doctors serving the Australian community. But a medical student can start today and it will be some 11 years before that student is fully qualified to practise. In the meantime, if we want to boost the supply of doctors in Australia, we do have to make appropriate and intelligent use of overseas trained doctors. Many communities depend upon overseas trained doctors. Some have been trained in the Third World. Many have been trained in countries such as England and Ireland, which have been traditional sources of overseas trained doctors for Australia-as indeed are our own doctors in practice in the UK and in Ireland. The overseas trained doctors practising in Australia are serving and helping the Australian community. This idea that anyone can migrate to Australia except a doctor is simply wrong. If someone comes to Australia who is appropriately medically qualified, it makes sense to make proper use of that person's talents. This idea that we should artificially restrict the ability of Australian residents and Australian citizens to practise in ways which serve the Australian community is simply wrong. I should finally point out that, notwithstanding the strictures of the member for Lalor, there are 10 overseas trained doctors filling positions in districts of work force shortage in her own electorate. I think the last thing the member for Lalor would want is for those 10 overseas trained doctors to be told that they are not wanted. I should also point out to the member for Lalor that 12 doctors in her electorate have taken up incentives offered by the government through the Metropolitan Doctors Scheme. While I would be the first to admit that, as time goes by, the government will further finetune its policies on the medical work force, any fair minded observer would have to say that the government has done a great deal, particularly under my distinguished predecessors Dr Michael Wooldridge and Senator Kay Patterson. I feel that I have done my best to fill their large shoes and to continue the important programs they put in place. I commend the bill to the House. Mr Katter-Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The minister said that I had been equivocal in my statements. It was a reflection upon me.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: I ask the member for Kennedy to resume his seat. The correct time for taking a point of order concerning your representation is after question time. I beg your pardon, the Clerk advises me that you can. Mr Katter interjecting

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Lalor has moved as an amendment that all words after ‘That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question. Question agreed to. Original question agreed to. Bill read a second time. Third Reading

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: HEALTH INSURANCE AMENDMENT
text: by leave-I move: That this bill be now read a third time. Question agreed to. Bill read a third time. NA AMENDMENT (SUPERANNUATION SAFETY AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 2005 Second Reading Debate resumed from 23 June, on motion by Dr Stone: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Title: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION
text: Hunter) (1.03 pm)I move: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, House: (1) notes that Australian workers and their families are: (a) not provided with full compensation in the event of theft and fraud from a superannuation fund; and (b) not provided with compensation for the loss of statutory 9% Superannuation Guarantee (SG) contributions in the event of employer insolvency under the General Employee Entitlements Redundancy Scheme (GEERS); and (2) recognising that superannuation is compulsory, long term and for retirement, calls on the Government to: (a) expand compensation for theft and fraud to 100% using the existing compensation mechanism; (b) examine the inclusion for payment of unpaid Superannuation Guarantee (SG) payments within the GEERS scheme; and (c) further consider a special provision for CSS members who applied for payments on CSS legal advice, later changed, to ensure payment is made for those who applied”.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION
text: Is the amendment seconded? Mr Stephen Smith-I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Title: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION
text: The Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Superannuation Safety and Other Measures) Bill 2005 amends relevant superannuation acts by changing some provisions for public servants to make them more consistent with the private sector regulation of superannuation. Specifically, the bill allows negative credit rates to be applied to member accounts in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. Allowing a negative credit rating will mean that the CSS, in line with other super funds, will apply a negative in a poor investment the year. Currently a ‘smoothing' is carried out in a negative earnings year by declaring a zero rate of return and transferring the losses forward to the following year or years by a reduction in the positive rate of return. This is carried out through a reserve account. Members' accounts up to 1 July 2006 will be quarantined. Only accumulations from this date will be affected. Maintaining smoothing is now very difficult for two reasons. Firstly, the introduction of investment choice will allow members to actively switch investments to higher risk categories. Members who do not do this subsidise members who do. Secondly, the CSS is closed and will experience a rapid decline in membership over the next 10 years. If negative earnings occur, the members who have left the fund due to retirement will be subsidised by the remaining members, who will be required to make up the losses. The bill also ensures that the operation of the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme and the CSS are consistent with the requirements of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 concerning fitness and propriety standards for superannuation fund trustees. This is a common sense approach and will ensure that a fit and proper person test, with the power of removal if an individual does not meet the test, covers public sector superannuation, as it does private superannuation trustees. It is a necessary safety improvement. The bill will validate the payment of benefits from the CSS made in error to a small group of fund members. This will validate payments made by the CSS to a small number of persons, probably in the hundreds, who, on legal advice to the CSS, were paid benefits. Subsequent legal advice after the payments had been made reversed the original legal opinion and concluded that such payments were not permitted by virtue of section 111A of the Superannuation Act 1976, as the fund members were still working. Given the circumstances, it would be unreasonable to go back to the individuals concerned and request repayment, as they may have spent or reinvested the moneys elsewhere. Labor supports the bill and provisions contained within. Given that this is a superannuation safety bill, Labor is greatly concerned about what is not in the bill. Labor has been greatly concerned for some years about further aspects of safety for superannuation: theft and fraud and employer insolvency. Labor has actively advanced policy to solve the gaps in protection. In respect of theft and fraud, the current law only guarantees protection for up to 90 per cent of moneys lost. The Howard government has tried unsuccessfully to reduce this even further, to 80 per cent. The current compensation mechanism provides that where theft and fraud occurs, a levy mechanism is applied across fund assets, currently totalling some $710 billion, to compensate the individuals affected. Fortunately, theft and fraud is minute in the context of total savings. This levy, when activated, represents a reduction of some 30c to 40c on members' fund balances. However, theft and fraud is catastrophic for the few hundred people who are affected each year. Given superannuation is compulsory, long term and for retirement, there is a very strong public interest argument that in these circumstances individuals should be fully compensated. Labor's second reading amendment reflects this goal. With respect to employer insolvency, the General Employee Entitlements Scheme, or GEERS, pays compensation for all unpaid wages, all accrued annual leave, long service leave and pay in lieu of notice, and up to eight weeks redundancy entitlements. Statutory entitlements and community standards are covered, except for one-that is, unpaid superannuation contributions under the superannuation guarantee act. Each year some 20,000-plus employees miss out on over $50 million in mainly compulsory superannuation contributions. Often the unpaid super is greater than other, protected entitlements. For example, a worker on a wage or salary of $50,000 a year who has, under GEERS, three weeks annual leave owing and a week's notice would receive approximately $4,300, but the unpaid super would amount to $4,500. The statutory superannuation payment is unprotected. Labor's second reading amendment calls on the government to consider extending the GEERS to protect this major statutory entitlement-that is, superannuation. Finally, I want to comment on the validation of payments made in error to a small group of CSS fund members. There was a further small group who, on legal advice from the fund, made applications for payments but were refused after a second legal advice was received. In many cases their lives were severely disrupted. They arranged and/or entered into arrangements on the basis they would receive this money. The Howard government certainly believed they should receive special consideration. The Minister for Finance and Administration, Nick Minchin, on behalf of the Liberal member for Solomon, Mr Tollner, wrote to a number of such persons ‘inferring' the government would assist. This has not happened. It is now clear that this was little more than a stunt during a difficult election period. bor's second reading amendment also goes to this very important issue. The opposition supports the bill and seeks support from the House for its second reading amendment.

Speaker: Mr BAKER
Title: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION
text: The Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Superannuation Safety and Other Measures) Bill 2005 will amend three acts: the Superannuation Act 1976, the Superannuation Act 1990 and the Superannuation Act 2005. The amendments result from the government's ‘safety of superannuation' reforms. The bill includes provisions to validate the payment of benefits to particular members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, allows negative crediting rates to be applied to amounts held in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and makes a number of minor amendments. The minor amendments include the provision to allow members of the staff of the boards of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme the delegation powers of the boards and to allow the boards to send documents to employees and any document or written information that, under the relevant scheme or act or any other act, they are required to send to the member. Under schedule 1, the bill makes amendments to provide for the application to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Board of the new fitness and propriety operating standard under SI(S) or Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, to provide for reduced reliance on acting members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Board and to provide for the use of proxies at board meetings. The bill will provide for the appointment of acting members to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme to comply with the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993. The bill allows the Commonwealth LaSuperannuation Scheme and the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme boards to delegate certain functions to staff and broadens the type of information that can be provided to members via their employers. The amendments will require that substantive and acting appointments to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme board do not contravene the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 fitness and propriety operating standard. The bill will also provide that the Minister for Finance and Administration may terminate the appointment of any board member who does not meet the standard. These amendments will place the same obligations on the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Board as for other trustees of superannuation funds in relation to having to comply with fitness and propriety requirements. The proposed amendments provide for members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Board to be able to participate in meetings when overseas, to vote and to disclose conflicts of interest at board meetings through proxies. New subsection 27N(4A) also provides that the appointment of the proxy is to be in writing and signed the appointing member. New subsection 27N(4B) provides that the proxy is not entitled to vote on behalf of the member on a proposed decision unless there is an instrument of proxy appointment which sets out the terms of the proposed decision and indicates whether the appointing member is in favour of or against the proposed decision, and the proxy member votes on the proposed decision in accordance with the indication in the instrument. The bill also makes amendments to the Superannuation Act 1976 and the Superannuation Act 1990 to broaden the type of information that can be provided to scheme members via their employers, provided that this would not breach the Corporations Act 2001 or any other act. Item 23 will amend paragraph 42A(1)(a)(ii) to allow the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme Board to request a designated employer provide to a member of the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme any information required to be provided by the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme Board to a member under any act. This is necessary as the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme Board is now required to provide information to members under other acts. I turn now to schedule 2, amendments relating to negative interest rates for the monwealth Superannuation Scheme. The bill will also amend the Superannuation Act 1976 to allow negative crediting rates, that is, negative earnings, to be applied to amounts held by members in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. When the proposed introduction of member investment choice was announced in 2004 the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Board requested that the restriction on the board declaring negative interest rates be removed to bring arrangements in line with industry practice. The amendments will therefore by provide the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Board with greater capacity than has applied in the past to equitably distribute earnings on the funded accumulation component of members' benefits between members who leave the scheme and those members who stay. The amendments will also allow the board more flexibility to accurately determine interest rates. Under current arrangements it is difficult for the Public Superannuation Scheme Board and the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Board to equitably distribute fund earnings between the members who leave the scheme and those who stay, especially when market conditions have led to negative fund reserves. Allowing negative crediting rates brings the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and the Public Superannuation Scheme into line with usual arrangements for funded accumulation components of superannuation benefits in that members will bear the risk of their investment choice. From 1 January 2006 the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Board will be able to make negative declarations of interest; however, the board will protect a member's account balance in line with the announcement it made in September 2004 that a member's account balance in the fund cannot fall below a certain level. The protected amount Comfrom 1 January 2006 will generally be the member's account balance in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Fund as at 1 July 2003 plus member contributions, including any transfer amounts, made between that date and 31 December 2005. An example of how this will operate is the case of Jenny. Jenny had an account balance in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Fund of $200,000 as at 1 July 2003. She paid $12,500 in contributions for the period 1 July 2003 to 31 December 2005 and has unallocated earnings of $50,000 for that period. Jenny subsequently pays $2,500 in contributions and has $10,000 in earnings for the period 1 January 2006, when the amendment commenced, to 30 June 2006. Jenny's protected amount is $212,500, which is made up of $200,000 plus $12,500, and if the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Board made a determination of interest as at 30 June 2006 that distributed all of the fund earnings, giving Jenny $60,000 in interest, her account balance would be $275,000 as at that date. The protected amount remains $212,500 irrespective of whether Jenny was in the default investment option or the cash conservative option when the amendments commence and irrespective of any switches she makes between the current options. If Jenny was a Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme deferred benefit member, and had been since 30 June 2003, her protected amount would be $200,000. I now turn to schedule 3, amendments relating to the validation of certain benefits under the Superannuation Act 1976. This bill will also amend the Superannuation Act 1976 to authorise a small number of Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme benefit payments that were incorrectly paid. These breaches occurred when members were paid Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme benefits without having met a condition of release under Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, such as having a termination of employment or attaining age 65. In most cases the affected members became Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme deferred benefit members when they joined an alternative superannuation arrangement operated by their employer and, after reaching their preservation age, commenced their Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme benefits, the main component being an indexed Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme pension, without having met a Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 condition of release. The amendments do this by recovering the unauthorised amounts that were paid in this manner as debts due to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Board by set-off of these recovered amounts against benefits payable, equal to the unauthorised amounts previously paid. It is intended that the set-off is not likely to involve any actual payment. In the case of future pension payments, the amendments in effect authorise the continued payment of the amount of the original pension that was previously unauthorised. The amendments also provide where act of grace payments have commenced in lieu of Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme benefits for a period of time before the commencement of the amendments that only the unauthorised Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme benefit amounts paid prior to the commencement of act of grace payments are able to be recovered by set-off against benefits payable. However, even where act of grace payments have been made, the amendments in effect authorise the recommencement of Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme pension payments of the amount of the previously unauthorised pension. Overall the amendments have the effect of prospectively authorising benefit payments, previously made available over a number of years to certain Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme members employed by certain approved authorities, in breach of superannuation law. Some examples of the effect of the amendments are as follows. For example, John commenced receiving his unauthorised Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme pension of $20,000 in February 2002, and he rolled over his member contributions and interest as a lump sum to another superannuation fund. In February 2005, John met a Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 condition of release because he reached age 65 and so he is authorised to receive Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme payments from that date. The effect of the amendments on John is that his unauthorised lump sum benefit is able to be recovered by set-off against a benefit of an equivalent lump sum benefit amount that is payable to him. The amount of the unauthorised pension paid to John for three years from February 2002 is able to be recovered by set-off against a benefit equal to the amount of that unauthorised pension that is payable to him. Future pension payments are, in effect, authorised to continue at the indexed amount of the previously unauthorised pension. Another example is Anita, who commenced receiving her unauthorised indexed Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme pension of $30,000 in January 1999 and she purchased an additional unindexed Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme pension of $10,000 per annum with her own contributions and interest. In March 2005 Anita was identified as being in receipt of unauthorised Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme payments and so the payment of these pensions was ceased forthwith and immediately replaced with act of grace payments of equivalent amounts in lieu. Anita meets a Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 condition of release on 1 July 2005. The effect of the amendments on Anita is that both her unindexed additional pension and her employer financed indexed pension of the period January 1999 to March 2005 are able to be recovered by set-off against benefits equal to the amount of her unauthorised pensions during that period that are payable to her. They do not affect the period when act of grace payments were made in lieu. Future pension payments are in effect prospectively authorised to continue at the indexed amount of the previously unauthorised pension. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mrs VALE
Title: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION
text: The Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Superannuation Safety and Other Measures) Bill 2005 will amend the Superannuation Act 1976, the Superannuation Act 1990 and the Superannuation Act 2005. These technical amendments are a consequence of the government's safety of superannuation reforms as well as changes required to facilitate the application of negative interest rates to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. The purposes of this bill are to amend the appointment provisions for members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme board in relation to the safety of superannuation reforms; to extend the delegation powers of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme board and the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme board; to allow the use of proxies at meetings of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme board for the purposes of voting and disclosing of interests; to amend the type of information that can be distributed by employers to the members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme; to allow negative crediting rates to be applied to amounts held in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme; and to authorise particular pension and lump sum Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme payments. The amendments will ensure that the operation of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme is consistent with the requirements of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 concerning fitness and propriety standards for superannuation fund trustees. This bill will also allow negative crediting rates to be applied to member accounts of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and validate the payment of benefits from the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme made in error to a small group of its members. A number of recent developments form the background to this bill, including Australia's new superannuation safety regime and changes that have taken place with the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme itself. Australia's new superannuation safety regime commenced on 1 July 2004, with a two-year transition for all existing trustees apply for a new registrable superannuation equity licence and to register their funds. The new regime not only involves a new licensing requirement but also sets standards for responsible officers and directors of trustees, adequate resources, outsourcing and risk management. Trustees that are operating at the commencement of the period will have until 30 June 2006 to obtain a licence and register the entities under their trusteeship. Persons or corporations not operating at the commencement of the period will not have the benefit of the transition period and will need to be licensed prior to commencing operations. To be eligible for a trustee licence, applicants must have robust frameworks in which to identify, measure and monitor the risks arising from the trustee operations and the risks specific to the entities for which they are trustee. These frameworks must be articulated in a formal risk management strategy and risk management plan. New operating standards have already been made covering the fitness and propriety of trustees, the requirement to hold adequate resources and the manner in which licensees outsource material business activities. These initiatives have brought the industry's corporate governance and risk management frameworks in line with other industries regulated by the Australian Prudential Regulatory Authority. Because of this initiative, effectively all superannuation trustees have to hold the appropriate licence by 1 July 2006. The Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme boards are in the process of applying for a superannuation trustee's licence. The majority of Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme board members are also Public Sector Superannuation Scheme board members. Another of the recent developments that to form the background to this bill came about on 11 August 2004, when the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme board decided to introduce investment choice for the fund's members. Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme members are now able to choose how their contributions are invested. This approach was implemented between November and December 2004 and was the first step in introducing a greater range of investment choices for Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme members. As a consequence of introducing investment choice for members, the way in which investment earnings were allocated to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme members' accounts was also changed. Prior to 1 July 2003 the earnings on members' accounts were determined by the calculation of the annual crediting rate. The crediting rate was the rate of return on a member's account for the previous financial year. Since 1 July 2003 the members' investment earnings have been determined on the basis of the exit rate. This is the estimated investment performance of the particular member's chosen investment option between 1 July 2003 and the date on which they exit the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, taking into account fees and taxes. The exit rate is applied to the member's account balance as at 1 July 2003 and to any subsequent contributions. When the crediting rate approach was used to calculate the investment return on funds, if the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme fund made an investment loss, and reserves were insufficient to cover that loss, the government paid what was necessary to cover the losses to the extent of the member's own contributions when the benefit was paid out. To reduce the financial risk to both the government and the members in the event of an investment loss, an investment reserve of five per cent of the assets of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme fund was established. If the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme made a loss, portions of the reserve were allocated to the member's account. Once investment earnings recovered, the investment reserve was gradually rebuilt to five per cent of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme's assets. While the investment reserve was being rebuilt the crediting rate was reduced, includtotal ing to zero, for that period of time. In this way continuing members shouldered a large proportion of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme's investment risk by forgoing investment earnings that they might otherwise have earned. Also, when the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme had made a loss and a member left, that member did not take the full extent of the losses them. The impact of rebuilding the investment reserve on the balances of the remaining members' accounts was, in these circumstances, greater than it might otherwise have been. This problem has the potential to have a significant impact in coming years. The Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme was closed to new members in 1990, and with no new members the scheme's membership profile has rapidly aged. This will result in a comparatively rapid decline in Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme membership over the coming years. If the policy for allocating investment losses and gains had not been changed, the situation might have arisen where a significant number of members exited the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme in a period when the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme experienced an investment loss. These members would not have taken a fair proportion of their investment losses with them and would have left the remaining members with a disproportionate impact on their accounts during the period over which the investment reserve was to be rebuilt. The new exit rate policy addresses these problems by applying the full extent of investment returns, and losses, continually to members' accounts. With the adoption of the exit rate as the basis for allocating the investment earnings, the operation of the reserves is now limited to situations where members' total credited balances exceed the assets of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. In such a situation, a negative reserve would be created and would need to be replenished from future earnings. The full implementation of the exit rate approach is hindered by the legal interpretation of the language used in the sections of the 1976 act to be amended by schedule 2 of this bill that the Commonwealth Superannuation with Scheme cannot declare a negative crediting rate to a member's account. Looking at the bill, schedule 1 contains provisions for amendments to the 1976 act, the 1990 act and the 2005 act. The schedule provides for the appointment and termination of members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme board to comply with the new fitness and propriety standard under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993. This bill will also provide for the appointment of acting members to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme board to comply with the superannuation supervision act. The amendments will require that substantive and acting appointments to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme board do not contravene the superannuation supervision act fitness and propriety operating standard. Also, the schedule provides a contravention of the standard would allow the Minister for Finance and Administration to terminate an appointment to the board. The proposed amendments will allow for reduced reliance on acting members of the board when substantive members are absent from Australia and provide for members to participate in, vote on and disclose conflicts of interest at board meetings through proxies. Similar amendments will be made to the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme in the scheme's trust deed and rules through an amending deed in respect of the above matters. The bill also includes amendments to the 1976 act, the 1990 act and the 2005 act allow the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme and the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme boards to delegate powers to their staff. This will improve the administrative efficiency of the boards. Other amendments to the 1976 act and the 1990 act will allow the boards to send to the designated employer of a member of the relevant scheme any document or written information that, under the relevant scheme act or any other act, they are required to send to the member. This change is necessary as the boards are now required to provide information to members under other acts. Schedule 2 of this bill provides for amendments to the 1976 act which will allow negative crediting rates to be applied to Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme member accounts. This initiative has the effect that members will bear the investment risk relating to their account balances, as appropriate. It will also provide the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme board with greater capacity to equitably distribute earnings between those members who leave the scheme and those who stay. Schedule 3 of the bill also provides for amendments to the 1976 act. This schedule will rectify the situation where a group of that Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme members have received benefits in breach of superannuation laws. They were deferred benefit members who had ceased contributory membership by joining an alternative superannuation arrangement offered by their employer. After they had reached preservation age they received payment of the benefits without meeting certain conditions such as terminating their employment or reaching age 65 as required. The amendments in the bill will effectively validate these payments. This bill provides for necessary technical amendments as a consequence of the government's reforms on safety of superannuato tion, as well as providing the changes to facilitate the application of negative interest rates to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION
text: Murray-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration) (1.36 pm)-In summing up this debate I would like to thank those who have participated. Indeed, it is a very important piece of legislation-one that is quite complex but of great concern to those who are growing older and need to make sure that their superannuation is safe and that they have appropriate coverage for their old age. The Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Superannuation Safety and Other Measures) Bill 2005 will amend the Superannuation Act 1976 in relation to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, often referred to as the CSS. The Superannuation Act 1990, which relates to the Public Sector Superannuation is Scheme, or PSS, is also amended by this bill. Finally, the bill amends the Superannuation Act 2005, which relates to the Public Sector Superannuation Accumulation Plan, or PSSap. Following the passage of this legislation, similar amendments will also be made to the PSS trust deed and rules under the Superannuation Act 1990 and to the PSSap trust deed under the Superannuation Act 2005. The bill primarily makes amendments to implement the government's safety of superannuation reforms by introducing a new fitness and propriety operating standard to the government's requirements of the CSS board. The bill also includes changes required to facilitate the application of negative crediting rates to the CSS, changes to validate the payment of benefits to particular members of the CSS and a number of minor amendments related to, for example, the use of proxies voting and the disclosure of interests by members of the CSS board, the delegation of powers of the CSS and PSS boards and the disclosure of information by those boards to employers. The Superannuation Act 1976 will be amended to provide that the appointment of a person as a substantive or acting member of the CSS board must not contravene the new fitness and propriety standards. The amendments will also provide for the minister to terminate a board member's appointment if they do not meet the standard. The bill will enable the CSS and PSS boards to allocate negative earnings to members' accounts. The board has requested these changes to allow allocation to members of actual fund earnings, including negative earnings, when member investment choice was introduced for relevant members in 2004. This will resolve the inequity where negative earnings are not passed on to members exiting the funds but are deducted from future earnings applicable to the remaining members' accounts. With member investment choice, it is appropriate that members bear the relevant investment risk in relation to their individual account balances. The bill will also amend the Superannuation Act 1976 to authorise a small number of CSS benefit payments that were incorrectly paid because ComSuper incorrectly informed certain members that they were entitled to claim their benefits. The effect of these changes will be that recovery from these individuals will not be required. The member for Hunter was concerned about this element and, indeed, included it as one of the elements of the amendment that he put forward. So I can assure him that the amendments in this bill well and truly cover those few individuals who were concerned in this way. In particular-I should elaborate a little for because this was a significant issue-there were some CSS members who did receive incorrect advice but who did not ever receive payments in relation to that advice. The problem was discovered, fortunately, very early and therefore before any benefit payments were made to the members. On being informed of the situation, the CSS board instructed its administrator, ComSuper, to immediately correct procedures and member information to ensure that no further benefits payments were commenced and undertook a review to establish the number of cases where payment may have been made incorrectly. At the time, relevant members whose applications had been or were being processed were personally contacted, and the CSS board also informed the office of the Minister for Finance and Administration, the minister's department and the relevant regulatory authorities. The issue was taken very seriously and dealt with very urgently and immediately. The other items in the amendment moved by the member for Hunter are not actually relevant to this particular bill. The bill will also make a number of technical amendments to enable CSS board members to appoint another board member as proxy, to clarify that CSS board members may participate in meetings by electronic or other means, to enable the CSS and PSS boards to delegate administrative functions to their staff and to broaden the type of information that can be provided by the CSS and PSS boards to scheme members via their employers. I commend this most important bill to the House.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION
text: The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Hunter has moved as an amendment that all words after ‘That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The immediate question is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question. Question agreed to. Original question agreed to. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation announced. Third Reading

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION
text: Murray-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration) (1.42 pm)-by leave-I move: That this bill be now read a third time. Question agreed to. Bill read a third time. NA (No. 1) 2005 Second Reading Debate resumed from 2 June, on motion  That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Title: CORPORATIONS AMENDMENT BILL
text: Hunter) (1.43 pm)I have recovered from that vicious attack by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration bringing into question the integrity of my amendment to the last bill and I am very pleased to be speaking on the bill before the House. The Corporations Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005 amends section 197 of the Corporations Act, effecting the potential indemnity of directors of corporate trustees from the liabilities of trusts. The intent behind the amendment is to ensure the directors of corporate trustees have a level playing field with regard to indemnity from liability as do directors of other entities. This is a clarification of section 197, and Labor supports the change. Specifically the amendment will clarify the potential personal liability of the directors of corporate trustees following the South Australian Supreme Court case in 2003, Hanel v ONEILL. In that case the court found that a director of a corporate trustee could be responsible for liabilities of the trust if the trust did not have sufficient assets to cover its liabilities. The effect of the decision in Hanel v ONEILL was that the liability of directors of corporate trustees could include the paying of all trust debts. This is a level of liability that extends beyond that of directors of other corporations and certainly beyond the original intent of section 197 of the Corporations Act. In assessing the need for this amendment, it is important to consider the recent legal history in this area. The current section 197 of the Corporations Act was preceded by section 229A of the companies code. Section 229A of the companies code, which was introduced into law in 1986, sought to ensure that on the insolvency of a corporate trading trust unsecured creditors did not have direct access to the trust's assets. Trading trusts had become popular business structures in the 1970s and there was recognition of the need both to limit the potential exposure of directors of corporate trustees to personal liability and to ensure that directors of corporate trustees were only indemnified from liability to the extent that they had acted properly and within the terms of the arrangement with the trust. Section 229A addressed this dual need by limiting the liability of directors of corpoof rate trustees to obligations for which the tee was not entitled to indemnity by reference to descending conduct which constituted a breach of trust between the corporate trustee and the interest of the trading trust. Section 229A later became section 233 when the Corporations Law came into effect in 1990. Then, under the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Act 1999, the new section 197 was introduced, with effect from 13 March 2000. When the Corporations Act came into effect on 15 July 2001, section 197 in its current form became law. The original section 229A of the companies code and later section 197 of the Corporations Act had operated in some obscurity until the interpretation by the South Australian Supreme Court in Hanel and ONEILL, where a broader interpretation of the potential liability of distructures rectors of corporate trustees was introduced. The effects of this interpretation I have already outlined. Given the history of these laws and the reasonable right of the directors of corporate trustees to indemnity from liabilities if they have met their obligations to the interest of the trust, the opposition accepts this amendment as a reasonable clarification of the intent of section 197. It is a change that will provide clarity to directors of corporate trustees and remove a potentially onerous burden on their business dealings. From the opposition's perspective, it is important also to note that this amendment to section 197 will not indemnify a director of a corporate trustee from liability if they commit a breach of trust or an act against the interests of the trust as per the trust agreement. This interpretation is in line with the original intent of section 229A of the companies code and a position which should be maintained. Labor has always sought to ensure that the Corporations Law balances the need of business proprietors for reasonable protection in the conduct their business affairs whilst ensuring that trusthere are adequate safeguards in place to prevent the abuse of those protections. This objective and intent of section 229A was foreshadowed by the then Attorney General, Lionel Bowen, on 11 October 1985, when in his second reading speech on the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1985 he said: Currently persons contracting with a trustee, whether an individual or a corporation, are entitled to be subrogated to the trustee's right of indemnity out of the trust assets to meet liabilities properly incurred. However if the trustee acts in breach of trust or in a manner which is not authorised by the terms of the trust, the trustee's right of indemnity, and therefore the creditor's right of subrogation, is lost. The problem this creates for creditors has been exacerbated by the widespread use of business involving a nominally capitalised corporate trustee to carry on business on behalf of a trust, together with other refinements, such as the careful siphoning of funds into the trust business. In such cases the creditor's primary right to sue the corporate trustee for the debt may well be worthless. I think there is a general recognition in the business community that the legal system cannot tolerate the continued use of artificial legal contrivances which result in the deliberate avoidance of liabilities legitimately owed to other persons. It is proposed to amend the Companies Act to impose personal liability on directors of companies acting as trustee when a debt has been incurred but the trustee company is not entitled to be indemnified out of the assets of the trust. With this considered view in mind, the opposition initially held reservations about the implications of the drafting of the current amendment set out in the bill. In particular, we were concerned that the terms of the amendment would limit its application to very narrow circumstances and thereby work against the objective of ensuring these provisions could not be abused. Labor have received advice from the office of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and have consulted with commercial lawyers familiar with Hanel and ONEILL. We are advised by the government that the intent of the amendment is not to diminish the potential liabilities of directors who have not met their obligations to the trading trust. On this basis, we do support the bill. Ensuring the right balance between the rights of directors and the rights of business stakeholders remains as important an objective now in Corporations Law as it ever was. Given these considerations, the proposed amendments to the potential liability of directors of corporate trustees bringing it into line with that of other directors is a sound objective. Labor has sought to cooperate with the government on this bill, recognising that certainty for many directors of incorporated trustees should be addressed as quickly as possible. As a result, Labor agrees with the amendment. It is a welcome clarification of the application of section 197 and should provide some certainty that directors of corporate trustees are seeking in this regard. Relationships between directors and other directors, directors and creditors and of course directors, creditors and administrators are an important part of our Corporations Law and crucial to the good operation of our economy. I should also include in that group the relationship between directors, creditors, shareholders and, of course, ASIC. Despite the best attempts by this parliament, too often these laws have let down participants in the system. I use as an example the case of Singleton Earthmoving. Singleton Earthmoving has now been trading as a corporate entity for some 25 years. For all of that time. I think it has been controlled by two directors, Mr Bernard Wood and his wife. According to Mr Wood, late last year his wife unilaterally appointed a third director. I have not yet been able to determine whether this was done lawfully in terms of the corporation, and ASIC refuses to offer any opinion on the matter. I do know that around September 2004 the second director was appointed and the two directors-other than Mr Wood-put the company into voluntary administration and appointed Mr Stuart Ariff as administrator. This was despite the fact that Singleton Earthmoving was a viable ongoing concern which was meeting all of its financial obligations to its various creditors. Around September Mr Ariff held a creditors meeting, which was subsequently adjourned. I understand that Mr Ariff assured creditors attending the meeting that no action on the company would be taken until such time as that meeting had been reconvened. Despite this, some weeks afterwards Mr Ariff took the action of having Singleton Earthmoving's plant and equipment seized and its phones disconnected. This of course resulted in Singleton Earthmoving no longer be a viable and ongoing concern. Indeed, it led to the retrenchment of 25 employees, some of whom were not paid for the month of September as a result. By 17 December, at a third meeting of creditors, Mr Ariff was recommending that the company be wound up. The creditors were amazed at this suggestion-these are creditors that had a good relationship with the company, in most cases for some 25 years-but, feeling that Mr Ariff was the expert in these matters and that they were very much in his hands, particularly given that the company was obviously not a viable ongoing concern any longer, and concerned about every opportunity available to them to secure the money owed to them, they decided that they would accept his recommendation and allow the company to be put into liquidation. On that point I would like to refer to parts of a letter that has been penned by all of the creditors to Mr Bernard Wood's former company. All of them believe that they have been mistreated and that the administrator-and now the liquidator-has acted inappropriately and they also believe that they collectively represent all of the creditors to the former company. They make 10 points. The first thing they question in point 1 is the legality of Mr Ariff's appointment as the administrator and, I suppose by implication, the legality of the appointment of the third director who, with the second director, used their majority to put the company into administration. They then go on to say in point 2 that at the first creditors meeting: ‘He'-that is Mr Ariff-‘was retained as administrator on the understanding that there would be no significant changes to the company's operation until the next meeting.' I take you back to my original point: there was that promise but, despite that promise, the plant and equipment of the company were seized and the phones disconnected. They go on to say that 10 days after the first meeting ‘without notice he forced the company to cease trading' by doing those things I have just mentioned. The third point they make is this: they complain about how he tried to prevent their client of over 20 years-that is, Mr Woodfrom trading. They say that despite Mr Ariff's attempts to stop their client trading, only has he prevailed successfully with the new company but they feel sure that without the administrator's actions the company would still be going on. They go on in point 4 to talk about how he successfully and quite callously without malice attempted to put 25 long-term employees out of work-and I made that point earlier on. In point 5 they talk about how, when the director who instigated the administrationthat is company director two in particularrealised her mistake or that a mistake had been made and tried to end the administration, Mr Ariff threatened her with Supreme Court action if she continued with her attempts to reverse the situation. They complain in point 6 about how, on 16 November 2004, Mr Ariff informed the creditors committee that one of the reasons for cessation of very trading was that there were no formal contracts in place with customers. The creditors say that their investigations showed that this was incorrect and there were indeed formal contracts in place. In point 7 they talk about how Mr Wood unsuccessfully tried to put in place a deed of company arrangement, which Mr Ariff blocked by various means, including harassment of various creditors to the company. In point 8 they talk about the December meeting at which Mr Ariff's solicitor threatened five creditors with Supreme Court action if they did not agree to his fees. In point 9 they talk about the three-month period after that meeting in which Mr Wood took a loan from the National Australia Bank to secure the assets again, a situation which, without Mr Ariff, would not have existed. In point 10 they complain about the continued strife for clients' businesses in that Mr Ariff had auctioned the property that their client had purchased from the National Australia Bank. I suspect that our Mr Ariff is a bit of a cownot boy. It is very unfortunate because what we had here was an ongoing viable business employing 25 people and there was never any suggestion of the company's inability to meet its obligations to its various creditors, including the finance company which held liens over the plant and equipment of the business. The last point the creditors make is that Mr Ariff is now asking for some $251,000 for fees in kind for the wonderful work he has done with respect to Singleton Earthmoving. I have made some inquiries of ASIC and I am still awaiting a response from ASIC. I hope that ASIC will be able to intervene in this case to the satisfaction of both Mr Bernard Wood and, of course, the creditors that have been burned by the actions of Mr Ariff. If ASIC is not prepared to act, then I will be asking the Treasurer to exercise his authority under section 14 of the ASIC Act to investigate Mr Ariff and direct ASIC to take the appropriate actions against him.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: CORPORATIONS AMENDMENT BILL
text: Order! It being 2 pm, the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 97. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed. NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: RULINGS
text: On 11 August the Manager of Opposition Business asked me to reflect on rulings on the content of questions, suggesting that there may have been inconsistency in my rulings. An analysis of the Hansard for both days shows no inconsistency. The rulings were consistent with each other and consistent with long standing interpretation of the standing orders. The rule applied in all examples cited is: A minister can only be questioned on matters of public affairs, administration and proceedings pending in the House for which he or she is responsible or officially connected. Therefore, the question on 10 August by the Manager of Opposition Business to the Treasurer about health expenditure was in order. The questions or parts of questions which were ruled out of order did not seek information from a minister which related to the minister's responsibilities. Examples of such out of order questions or parts of questions include: asking the Deputy Prime Minister for an opinion on his performance without referring to any particular aspect of his responsibilities; asking the Minister for Education, Science and Training to comment on a quotation from a senator; and asking the Deputy Prime Minister if his policy related to the views of a senator. Furthermore, questions or parts of questions which relate to the minister's official responsibilities are of course in order. However, it is out of order to ask a minister to comment on a statement made by another person. The only exception to the rule is that the standing orders specifically allow a question to the Prime Minister on whether a minister's statement in the House represents government policy. NA

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS
text: I inform the House that the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources will be absent from question time today and tomorrow. He is travelling overseas to Chile, Mexico and the United States to promote Australia as an investment destination. The Deputy Prime Minister will answer questions on his behalf. NA Telstra

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Minister, isn't it a fact that the CEO of Telstra told the Telstra board that Australia lags behind its international peers in terms of investment, the take-up of broadband services, pricing and capacity, and that Australia is in the bottom quartile of developed countries in terms of its telecommunications services? Isn't it also a fact that the Telstra CEO told the government that fixing the communications problems in the city and the bush in their initial phase would cost $5.7 billion? With a task so vast, isn't the only way to future proof Telstra's services to keep Telstra in public ownership?

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. The answer is no. Economic Outlook

Speaker: Mr MCARTHUR
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer outline to the House recent information on wage costs? What are the implications of this data for the inflation outlook? Are there any measures that can be taken to further improve labour market outcomes?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Corangamite for his question. I can inform him that the labour price index for the June quarter of this year showed a slight acceleration of wage costs, rising four per cent through the year to the June quarter of 2005, which was marginally up from the 3.9 per cent through the year to the March quarter of 2005. These wage costs show that there are real wage increases going on in the community but they are restrained and consistent with low inflation, provided the economy maintains productivity growth. Indeed, the Reserve Bank governor, in his testimony last Friday, noting that the wage cost index was 3.9 per cent, described it as ‘remarkably well behaved'. The member for Corangamite also asked about measures to improve labour market outcomes. I know that this is of real interest to him because he asked the Governor of the Reserve Bank questions to this effect in Melbourne on Friday. The governor was asked why Europe was showing slow economic growth compared to Australia. The Governor of the Reserve Bank said: I think the biggest single explanation is that they have very old-fashioned, heavily overregulated economies. … … One of the forms of heavy regulation in Europe is labour market regulation. It is extraordinarily heavy labour market regulation, most of which has the effect-as a lot of regulations do-of protecting the insiders at the expense of the outsiders.
