Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have received a letter from the honourable member for Wills proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely: The Government's plans to sell Telstra and its squandering of the proceeds of the partial sale of Telstra. I call upon those members who approve of of the the proposed discussion to rise in their places. More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Today we have heard that the government is getting set to sell Telstra and that the National Party is all set to fall into line, in particular Queensland National Party senator Barnaby Joyce-Backdown Barnaby. This must be a world record for the shortest time ever spent as a maverick in the Senate. They should put it on that Sunday night TV show Australia's Guinness world records. Barnaby Joyce arrives in Canberra last week. He gets shirt fronted by Senator Heffernan and the member for O'Connor, old Ironbar. Five minutes later, what remains? Barnaby Rubble. Five minutes of political sunshine, Barnaby. Hope you enjoyed it. The National Party is always ready to sell out its constituency provided the price is right. We on this side of the House always knew they would sell out, because that is the nature of the National Party. Now they are led by a former auctioneer. Some people might think this is highly appropriate-a political party that will sell anything provided the price is right being led by an auctioneer. But he is a strange kind of auctioneer: Telstra offered $5 billion and he sold for $3 billion. I don't know about you, but I would not want him selling my house. The pity and the tragedy of it is that the Leader the National Party is selling off something of far more value-an asset Australians have built up over the course of a century and something which, once it is lost, can never be regained. The members of the National Party will be out there trying to claim that this is a win. least Backdown Barnaby has the grace to still maintain that Telstra should not be sold, that the best interests of Australians would be served by Telstra continuing to remain in majority public ownership. But the rest of The Nationals will be out there claiming that there is now $3 billion available to compensate country people for the loss of the publicly owned Telstra-$1 billion for capital investment and $2 billion for a fund to pay for upgrades to the rural telecommunications network. The first point that ought to be observed here is that telecommunications is not just an issue for rural and regional Australia. The sale of Telstra is not just bad for country Australia; it is bad for all of Australia. is no suggestion that the outer metropolitan areas, for example, are going to get anything out of this. All they will get is poorer services and higher charges. But the National Party will be out there spruiking this $3 billion in a ‘never mind the quality, feel the whip' selling job. But wait, haven't we heard this before? What became of the money that they got from the first sales of Telstra, which brought in $17 billion and $16 billion respectively? Back then they set up the Natural Heritage Trust to enlist the support of the green groups for the sale. The green groups fell for it and were duly conned-as you always are when you deal with this government. Firstly, the government slashed spending from the environmental part of the budget on the basis that it was no longer needed on acof count of Telstra and the Natural Heritage Trust money. Secondly, they turned it into a government slush fund, with the vast majority going to Liberal and National Party held electorates. Thirdly, they wasted the money and failed to deliver real improvements for the Australian environment, which has conAt tinued to deteriorate on all the objective measurements during their time in office. The Auditor-General found it impossible to work out what benefits, if any, Australians got from the Natural Heritage Trust because the government-oops-forgot to monitor the projects and collect any genuine data about the outcomes. They simply handed the money over and walked away-no monitoring, no evaluation. I have talked about that before. Today, I want to talk about Networking the Nation. As the Howard government prepares to sell the remainder of Telstra, the House needs to ask: what do we have to show for the $3 billion distributed to groups in regional Australia following the T1 and T2 Telstra sales unThere der the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund? Very little of it in fact resulted in infrastructure. Instead, the government handed out large numbers of grants to groups in regional Australia for services rather than for infrastructure. Many of the groups had little expertise or track records. Most were unable to establish viable projects. The opportunity to build regional infra- set structure was blown away with a host of grants that have been of little lasting value regional Australia. Networking the Nation was one subprogram of the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund, funded with around $500 million of Telstra sale money. In one scathing audit report-and there were several-the Auditor-General found that the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts did not have an appropriate management framework in place to monitor the efficiency and effectiveness of Networking the Nation programs and that it had inadequate needs assessment and risk assessment, a lack of measurable targets and significant numbers of outstanding project reports and acquittals. That was in Audit Report No. 12 2003-04. Investigations show that much of the money from the first two Telstra sales was wasted. For example, there were 130 taxpayer grants to New South Wales rural projects after the first Telstra sale, but one in four of those grants did not add a single telephone or internet service to the bush. Instead, 27 per cent of the grants funded studies, strategies, needs assessments and training programs. More than $95 million of the telecommunications funding promised to the bush was later withdrawn by the government and counted as savings or spent on other projects. An audit report into the programs was highly critical of the lack of accountability imposed on those who received the grants. It found that administration costs soaked up 27 per cent of one program to set up 500 rural transaction centres. Yesterday, the wellrespected Byron Shire Echo gave a detailed report of what had happened on the North Coast of New South Wales: The Nats made Networking The Nation, in part up as a ‘social bonus' of earlier Telstra sales, a very useful pork barrel from 1997 to 2004. The to north coast was awash with NTN funds in its heyday. It was probably no hindrance that the chairman of NTN was Doug Anthony, father of then Richmond MP Larry Anthony. It was no hindrance at all. The article then asks the question: But have the NTN funds done anything much to improve telco services on the north coast? The paper asks a very good question. The article continues: Over $2 million in public funds went into Norlink, the internet provider originally supported by local business and community organisations. On May 26 this year Norlink went into voluntary administration ... … … … Its vision of a series of ‘E-towns' supported by local councils was not realised and its presence did not make it as far as Kyogle, one of the intended towns. It operated online from MAP, the Mullumbimby ISP it acquired, and offers a wireless service. As of last Thursday morning online documents still bore the logos of groups which have since sought to distance themselves from Norlink. The NSW Farmers Association says it has had no association with Norlink for a number of years and the Northern Rivers Regional Development Board abandoned administrative support to the company in 2000. As the paper also says: What Norlink had achieved is little different to that done by local businesses such as Linknet. No over-arching plan has emerged from NTN to give the bush a wealth of high speed connections. The article also mentions the case of Bangalow businessman Christopher Sanderson, who received $894,000: ... for an online produce marketing service called variously TAFTCO and Grower Direct. An earlier incarnation of Mr Sanderson's project was the Regional Internet Marketing Cooperative which was involved with the Northern Rivers Agricultural Development Corporation (NORADA), actively promoted by Doug Anthony. Its efforts to find Asian markets for Australian growers were found wanting by some members of the NSW Farmers Association. The article continues: The ghost of the Grower Direct company still exists online ... Brisbane produce software company Freshcomp Computer Systems, which is linked to the Grower Direct site, told the The Echo it never had an association with the Bangalow company. There was another north coast telco service to benefit from NTN funding, the Southern Cross University's CoastCall business initiative. It received over $385,000 and ran for a couple of years, with most of the money being spent on administration. Its 2000 report admitted that CoastCall had no success in attracting advertising and that it was not worth hiring reps to go after it. The Echo says: For the most part, NTN funds seem to have disappeared or been‘hosed up'; they actually used more robust languageagainst the e-wall. If the Nats are successful getting another slush fund, will it all happen again? That is a very good question. As far back as September 1998, the New South Wales Farmers Association's Coffs Harbour regional branch was using Networking the Nation as an example of its concerns that ‘often grants earmarked to assist the community never reach those they are intended for'. A letter from the association says: After more than 12 months of operating, benefits from over $200,000 of funding are yet to flow on to the farmers. Northern Rivers Agricultural velopment Corporation and the Regional Internet Marketing Cooperative continue along their chosen path without any involvement of the farming community. In relation to this failed $894,000 project, there are plenty of questions to be answered by the government. The businessman associated with this grant, Mr Christopher Sanderson, will now not field questions from journalists about the project. When the government is asked to account for this expenditure, it simply emails a link to the Grower Direct web site, which itself has links to other company sites. Those companies have told various media outlets that they never had any association with the company. So the question is: just how was that $894,000 grant money spent? Has any of it found its way into Jindi-Net, a wireless broadband network run from Jindibah-an ‘intentional community', whatever that means-by none other than Mr Christopher Sanderson, the recipient of the grant money? Labor will be taking up the fight on this issue. We will require that this and many other Networking the Nation acquittals lodged with the department are produced. It seems that the only thing the community has to show for almost $1 million to improve regional telecommunications is the digital ghost of the Grower Direct web site. It is a in shameful legacy that does not augur well for other regional projects meant to compensate the bush for the ghost of Telstra public ownership. Australians throughout country Australia need to be warned. They have been sold a dummy on regional telecommunications infrastructure before and it will happen again. One of the things that you can be absolutely guaranteed of is that Telstra money will be used to fund a government advertising campaign-money from the sale of a national asset paying for Liberal and NaDe- tional Party propaganda. Last year, the campaign Working to Keep the Country Connected-don't you love those Orwellian titles?-hit rural and regional airwaves from May to July. Of course it was entirely coincidental that this was in the lead-up to the federal election. That campaign swamped rural and regional TV and radio stations, as well as newspapers, with advertisements to inform people about their telecommunications rights. I am asked about the costs. The total advertising campaign cost in 2003-04 was $5 million. In 2004-05 it was $953,000. So nearly $6 million was spent in total, yet only $73,000 of this amount was spent on printing the booklet-Your Phone Service. Your Rights-that this advertising campaign was supposed to promote. As it happens, an answer to a question from Senator Faulkner indicates that, despite over $3½ million of taxpayers' money being spent on TV, radio and newspaper advertising placements, as of 1 June 2004 only 971 calls had been logged at the tel:info helpline. This means that between 9 May and 1 June on average only 40 people per day right across Australia-that is two people per hour-called the helpline at the peak of the advertising campaign. That it is a pathetically low response for a campaign that cost almost $6 million. Since the 2004 election, it has all melted away and is no longer available online-so much for keeping the country connected. The partial sale of Telstra was a mistake; the complete sale will be a bigger mistake. It is being proposed by people who ought to know better. Networking the Nation simply turned into a National Party pork barrel and millions of taxpayers' dollars were wasted. If the Howard government privatises the rest of Telstra, the National Party will again turn as much of the proceeds as it can into a National Party slush fund. It will be another massive waste of public money. (Time expired)

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Murray-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration) (3.35 pm)-I am absolutely staggered that Labor would invite the public to hear what they did in their 13 years in government for telecommunications across this great country and what the John Howard led government has willingly undertaken since 1996 to bring back a more equitable system of telecommunications, one that is competitive and one that delivers world-class opportunities to those who have to communicate to survive. I was amused that the member for Wills spent a lot of time in his remarks on the spending of some of the first partial sale of Telstra funds, saying what an appalling thing it was to spend these funds on the biggest environmental program Australia has ever seen. I was parliamentary secretary to the environment minister while the member for Wills was the opposition spokesman for the environment. I remember that he said again and again-it is the only contribution he ever made to environmental debate-that the problem with the Natural Heritage Trust was that Labor seats were not getting enough of it and that there should have been more spending on that magnificent program in Labor held seats. As various reviews showed, the relationship of the allocation of funds matched almost exactly where the seats were in the landscape. It is a simple case that rural and regional voters do not vote for the Labor Party. The seats which have the environmental issues tend to be in the hands of the coalition. I suppose that is why we were not so surprised that in 1996, when the Labor Party's telecommunications policy was revealed for all to scrutinise, the word ‘regional' appeared but once. Not a cent of the Labor Party's telecommunications policy was committed to telecommunications for rural or regional people-not a cent. Was that because Labor had built up, in the previous 13 years, a magnificent system that served rural, regional and metropolitan Australia? Let us remind ourselves of what telecommunications in Australia was all about under Labor. bor policy. Mr Hartsuyker-Shame!

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Indeed. If you had just built a new home or started a new business, and you wanted the phone connected-probably the most important thing you can do in a new business is to have the phone connectedunder Labor it took up to 27 months. That is over two years. Can you imagine it? Mr Hartsuyker interjecting

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Cowper may wish to speak in this debate in a moment.

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Businesses went broke. People gave up and walked away. There were domestic tragedies. There were people who could not cope because, under Labor, they could not get the phone connected at their new home for over two years. That is disgusting. Under a Liberal led coalition, today only 20 days are required to get a new service hooked up to your new home or business. And we are expecting to see that number come down even further. That 27 months compared to 20 days is just one example-and a pretty interesting example-of what happened with telecommunications under Labor. They presided over a TelstraOptus duopoly that was uncompetitive. The money made went back into those outfits rather than into new technology. There was no universal service obligation in place to make sure that country or suburban people got a fair go; hence, there was a two-year waiting time for a new phone. It was absolutely disgraceful. Let me remind those on the other side of the House what we on this side know-and, because you do not represent rural and regional people, you probably did not realise-that, under Labor, mobile service coverage actually contracted in rural and regional Australia. Mr Hartsuyker-Shame! That was La

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I don't know that it was Labor policy

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Cowper is warned!

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I suspect it was just that they did not understand what it meant not to be able to use telecommunications in rural and regional areas. So, in a deal done in 1993 with Vodafone, Labor said: ‘We'll let you do a certain sort of business. We'll make it viable for you by withdrawing the analog mobile service. It will have to close by the year 2000.' When we came into government in 1996, we could not undo that contract; the cost to the taxpayer would have been too great. So, right across the country in 2000, analog services were shut down. Thank you, Labor. That was a most appalling decision you made back in 1993. We saw mobile services contract under your regime. The member for Wills was most excited when he listed project after project that had been funded through the partial sale of Telstra in addition to the magnificent environmental program. Let us look at what has been done by the Howard led coalition since 1996 by way of improvements in telecommunications. We tackled the problem that we inherited from Labor with three major strategies. The first strategy was to encourage competition to deliver innovation, cheaper prices and greater choice. As a result of our work, the price of phone calls in Australia has come down by 20 per cent since 1996. I will be reminding those opposite of that figure quite a few times. Ms George-What about line rental costs?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: If the member for Throsby wishes to speak, she can seek the call.

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Our second plank was to establish and maintain a tough regulatory consumer safeguard regime with price controls, a customer service guarantee and the universal service obligation. We do not believe you should simply leave it to the carriers to do as they will. We have put in very tough safeguards and they will continue to be there. That is why we have given a better go for rural, regional and outer-suburban people when it comes to their services. The third plank is targeted funding to improve services, particularly in areas that are not served, or not well served, by the market because, for example, they are very remote or have a very low population density. What have we achieved through the three main planks of our policy? Firstly-and I have already mentioned this-the price of services has fallen by 20 per cent. Customers have greater choice of service provider than ever before. This continues to drive competition, which brings down prices and stimulates innovation, leading to new services being rolled out all the time. We have had some independent evaluation-not in house as the member for Wills suggests-from the Allen Consulting Group. The evaluation was authorised by the Australian Communications Authority and it looked at what the telecommunications reforms have delivered to Australia since 1996. It found the telecommunications reforms have increased the size of the Australian economy by $12 billion. It found we have created approximately 4,000 new jobs with the new competition and the expansion of services, and we have delivered benefits to small business of $1.8 billion. We have not denied them a phone for two years; we have actually delivered benefits to small business of at least $1.8 billion. On average, each Australian household is $759 better off as a result of our telecommunications strategy since 1996. Ms George-You've gotta be joking!

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Throsby is warned!

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: That is a very significant saving for households, indeed. There are now more than 100 telecommunications carriers operating in Australia and I am sure there are going to be more. Of course, they compete and help with innovations. There are more than 16 million mobile phones in operation in Australia. People can now choose whether they even install a landline phone in their house or apartment: they can just rely on mobile phones. The number of broadband subscribers in Australia is now well over one million. Ms George interjecting

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Throsby will remove herself from the House understanding order 94(a). The member for Throsby then left the chamber.

Speaker: Dr STONE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: This is an example of the competitive environment we now have: almost half of Telstra's ADSL subscriptions are wholesale services that are being resold to competitors. Since 1997 the Howard government has committed more than $1 billion to improving telecommunications infrastructure and services in Australia. As I have just shown with that independent evaluation, the $1 billion investment has delivered in manifold ways, in terms of added value and choice, to our great Australian nation. This expenditure has covered programs including Networking the Nation and the social bonus, which came about as a result of our very intensive Besley and Estens inquiries. We always listen hard and we will continue to review. The most recent commitment was for more than $180 million in response to the Estens inquiry. So we have delivered, in the way that I have just described. And what an extraordinary achievement, given what we had to deal with-the neglect of telecommunications under Labor, particularly for rural and regional people who were in despair when it came to trying to do ness and run social lives and communities when they simply could not connect. Today there has been an announcement. It is probably one of the most significant announcements for telecommunications since our initial policy launches in 1996. It is a continuation of the magnificent work that has been ongoing since 1996. It is called Connect Australia. I want to applaud our Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Helen Coonan, who has done a magnificent job, and all of the committees, the Liberal and National Party backbenchers, the middle benchers and the ministers who have worked to make this new policy one of the most significant announcements that we have ever seen in telecommunications services in Australia. We have reannounced our commitment to first-class communications services for tralia. We will continue to deliver on that promise, with a $1.1 billion roll-out of broadband, new regional clever networks, mobile services and special telecommunications services for Indigenous communities, who are often in the most remote parts of our great country. As well as that $1.1 billion, there will be $2 billion dedicated to a communications fund. This will be established, and the earnings from the fund will be used to provide new communications services for rural Australia. The government will also provide a more robust regulatory framework for the telecommunications industry. We will not do what Labor did: simply hope and pray that something good will happen. Quite simply, you need a watchdog in this world and we will maintain the strongest of safeguards to protect our consumers. (Quorum formed) Let me say in these last few seconds that you will have to do better than that to shut down busithe fact that telecommunications in this country were a disgrace before 1996. They were appalling. Now Australia has some equity, some good cost products and some innovative technology. I want to commend our government and particularly Senator Helen Coonan for the magnificent job that she has done. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr EDWARDS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I simply have to ask, after having listened to the government speaker at the table: if Telstra is so good, why sell it? It is interesting to look through the public media reports of recent weeks. First of all we saw Prime Minister HowardGovernment members-Get over it.

Speaker: Mr EDWARDS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: If you want to come in and join the debate, do so. It is interesting, having looked through the media reports, to have seen of late Prime Minister Howard bullying poor old Sol. We saw Senator HefAus- fernan bullying ‘Backdown Barnaby', who obviously heard his master's voice, and we have seen the Nats today again take 30 pieces of silver.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Cowan will refer to members by their title.

Speaker: Mr EDWARDS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: It is interesting indeed that the National Party have obviously plucked, trussed, stuffed and cooked the Telstra goose, and now they simply sit waiting to carve it up. Christmas may be coming early to the bush, but it is the rest of Australia that will be putting the presents under the tree. There is no doubt that Telstra will be sold. Australia will be sold out, and Australian mums and dads will be paying more for poorer services. The interesting thing during most of this debate, one which you would think the National Party would have some real interest in, is that the National Party has been outnumbered in this chamber by the Independentsand there are only two of them. What an absolute disgrace! The sale of Telstra is bad for the bush, bad for the budget and bad for Australia. I pose this question to the government members: if the sale of Telstra is not in the interests of Australian families, how can it possibly be in the national interest? I also want to put this to the government members: if the partial sale of Telstra has been good Australia, let us see the tangible benefits of the proceeds of that partial sale. Where are they? I challenge the government to tell and show not just the residents of my electorate in the northern suburbs of Perth but all the Australians who live in the fringes of our cities where the benefits of the partial sale have gone. The government cannot or will not answer that question, but I will. The proceeds of the partial sale have been squandered. They have been squandered on buying votes in the bush and through the bulbous pockets of the government's spendthrifts, who have wasted countless opportunities for proper and prudent investment in our infrastructure, our services and our future. The proceeds have been squandered by the biggest porkbarrelling government in the history of Australia-squandered and wasted, not invested. The government have not invested in infrastructure, in growth, in their loyal clientele, in the future of our nation, in Telstra's employees or in the growth of Telstra. Indeed, Telstra has been downgraded and its services have been downgraded by the government in their rush to sell the asset and get their hands on the money. I had a look at some figures that I used in an earlier debate, which showed that capital expenditure in Telstra had fallen from a peak of $4.75 million in 1999-2000 to an estimated $3.25 million in 2002-03. Where did the investment go? We also know that, during those same years, staff were shed at a rate of some 4,000 full-time employees per year. Is it any wonder that the government benches are almost bare? They certainly do not like to be reminded of these facts. I recently made some inquiries in Western Australia, because we are constantly, daily, getting complaints from small business people who work from home, from small business people in the industrial areas in the for northern suburbs of Perth and from mums that their telephone services are not up to scratch. I was told that there is a department within Telstra called the CNI, which stands for customer network improvement. This department is for the more major faults, not for average repairs. I am told that if a technician attends a fault complaint they often find that the problem is more serious than just fixing the line at one person's home. If this type of fault is located, the attending technician tries to temporarily fix the problem with the line and then reports the fault to the CNI, the customer network improvement department, and this department fixes the major faults. There are currently 8,000 to 9,000 outstanding CNI fault reports in the Perth metropolitan area. That is incredible. Where is the investment? Where has the money from the previous, partial sale of Telstra gone? Where is the growth of Telstra? What we have seen is not a growth but a decline. Infrastructure and investment have not kept pace with technology and growth, and not just in urban parts of our cities. They have certainly lost ground when you compare the growth with small business, which relies on Telstra and its services to enable it to compete. It is a bit hard trying to get more specific figures out of Telstra because, quite frankly, Telstra is embarrassed at its lack of infrastructure investment, its lack of services, the number of faults that it has to deal with and the amount of time it takes to deal with those faults. About 18 months or so ago the government ran a Telstra seminar in the northern suburbs of Perth. The then minister, Daryl Williams-since retired-told that meeting that Telstra is not responsible for supplying broadband services. That was the view of the minister who had responsibility for Telstrathat Telstra is not responsible for supplying broadband services. An opposition member-What does it do?

Speaker: Mr EDWARDS
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The question is asked: what does it do? Whatever it does, the minister of the day, whether then or now, does not seem to know, because one of Telstra's employees had to rush out and put out a press release through the northern suburbs saying that Telstra was committed to rolling out ADSL where there was sufficient demand. There is sufficient demand. That demand is in our cities and it is in the bush-it is right across Australia. It is a great pity, a great shame, that this government has chosen not to invest in the future of Telstra and chosen not to invest in the future of Australia. It has turned its back on Telstra and it has turned its back on Australia. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr HARTSUYKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I am delighted to have the opportunity to speak today on this matter of public importance. In my discussion I want to touch on three points: firstly, the government's record in delivering telecommunications improvements to the people of Australia; secondly, the announcements made today on the $1.1 billion Connect Australia program and the $2 billion Communications Fund for the future; and, thirdly, the track record of the ALP on both telecommunications and privatisation. On the first point, the government's track record since coming to power in 1996, the coalition has delivered unprecedented benefits to Australian consumers and businesses through the development of a highly competitive telecommunications regime. We as a government have been focused on equity and access to high-quality telecommunications services across Australia, no matter where you live. There have been three planks in the government's approach to achieving those objectives: firstly, to encourage competition, to deliver innovation, to deliver cheaper prices and to deliver greater choice; secondly, to maintain tough regulatory and consumer safeguards such as price controls, customer service guarantees and universal service obligations; and, thirdly, to provide targeted funding to provide services in areas which would not normally be catered for in a commercial market. The government's approach has delivered real benefits to consumers: prices have fallen, customers have been offered a choice of providers and new services such as broadband are being rolled out across the country. Since the introduction of competition in 1997, consumers have seen a decrease in prices of some 20 per cent in real terms for telecommunications services. Now Australians can choose between different service providers and different telecommunications products. Australians have the option of dealing with 100 carriers across Australia, and there are now more than 16 million mobile phones in operation. Broadband subscribers now number well over a million, with half of them being serviced by operators other than Telstra. Regional Australia has benefited in particular from the improvements under this government, with over a billion dollars being spent to date on a range of programs, such as Networking the Nation and improvements under the Besley and Estens reviews, including the highly successful HiBIS program which delivers broadband to small communities right round the country. There is also $50 million metropolitan black spot program. This government has invested over $140 million to support the extension of mobile phone coverage to 98 per cent of Australians. Under the coalition, 40,000 customers living in remote Australia have access to untimed local calls for the first time, and they have been given the opportunity to take up subsidised two-way high-speed satellite internet services. I would now like to turn to the announcement made today. This additional commitment will build on what has gone before under this government. The $1.1 billion Connect Australia program will provide a huge boost to our national infrastructure, with $878 million for the Broadband Connect program to provide more Australians with affordable broadband services; $113 million for the Clever Networks program, which will roll out new broadband networks to provide innovative applications to improve delivery of health, education and other essential services; $30 million for the Mobile Connect program to further extend terrestrial mobile coverage to areas not adequately catered for and to build on the subsidy for handheld satellite phones; and $90 million for a comprehensive package to provide telecommunications services to our Indigenous communities, which are so lacking in telecommunications services. The government believes that good telecommunications services need to be assured not only now but into the future, and that is why there will be a system of regular reviews of services. There will be a requirement for Telstra to produce a local presence plan to ensure that Telstra services able in regional and rural Australia and that there will be access to Telstra representatives at the local level. A $2 billion fund will be established, the revenue from which will be invested to ensure that we will be able to roll the out improved technologies in telecommunications as they occur. That is a vitally important factor: future-proofing regional and rural areas to ensure that they have the adequate services they need not only now but into the future. We believe that better competition is the key to better services and lower costs. As part of this proposal, the government will require the operational separation of Telstra's wholesale and retail business units. If we are going to have proper competition other carriers will need to have a level playing field and, through operational separation, the National Party and the Liberal Party believe we will be able to achieve that. The government seeks to ensure transparency in pricing for wholesale customers. There will also be price controls: the 22c untimed local call will be maintained, there will be no large increases in line rental, there will be restrictions on the cost of new connections and there will be measures to protect low-income earners. This government is encouraging a reduction in telecommunications costs to the Australian community. I would now like to turn from the bright future to the dark past of Labor's history, to Labor's appalling record on telecommunications, particularly in regional and rural areas. It is difficult to recount their strategy on regional services because I do not think they really had one. The word ‘regional' barely appeared in their policy. Not one cent was committed to improving services in rural and regional areas. As I said, ‘regional' was mentioned only once in their policy. Labor's record on mobile phones was a disgrace, switching off the analog service and putting are availnothing in its place. As the member for Murray said previously, services were actually reduced under Labor, not increased. That amounts to vandalism of the community's telecommunications services. It took this coalition government to roll out the replacement CDMA network. When Labor was in government it placed no requirements on Telstra to fix or install services within time limits. Waiting for over two years for a landline connection is deplorable but it was part of the day under Labor. People were waiting for two years for a phone connection. These days there is a 20 working days maximum. Labor did not encourage competition in telecommunication markets as there was a duopoly between Telstra and Optus. This did not see substantial reductions in prices, have seen in the recent past. It was a coalition government that delivered price competition. Some try to argue that quality of vices can be delivered through the control of Telstra. Actually, Telstra is controlled by regulation, not through ownership. Labor's plan for Telstra, as far as we can see, would see a return to the bad old days of having a monopoly. Labor do not seem to have a forward vision for telecommunications. Their only response to the telecommunications argument is that of public ownership. They think public ownership is the key-back to the days of the PMG. This government is looking forward. Labor have no vision for telecommunications. Labor have no vision to take this country forward with telecommunications infrastructure. Their only policy initiative is to look backwards, to try and retard the government in its efforts to provide improved services-to try and replace its forward vision with an idea that takes us back to the past. If you ask people around my electorate, perhaps in South West Rocks or Wooli, whether they like the roll-out of mobile phone towers, I am sure they would say they do. I am sure the people of Bonville are pleased to have the broadband that has been delivered under the broadband rollout. It is a ridiculous notion that this government is not delivering. The National Party and the Liberal Party are absolutely committed to delivering quality telecommunications services. Labor have squandered the proceeds that they received through the privatisation of Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank. They privatised those companies and still could not run a balanced budget. This government has been able to invest the proceeds of the sale of Telstra into improved telecommunications services. The member for New England is in the as we chamber. He obviously does not have a vision for telecommunications in his electorate. He wants the bad old days of full public ser- ownership. He wants to provide steam powered internet services for his electorate! He does not see the benefits of improved telecommunications services, as this government do. We want to take this country forward. We do not want to see steam powered internet services, as is the vision of the member for New England. We want to see highquality, high-speed broadband rolled out across the country as quickly as possible. We want to see a competitive regime for the provision of telecommunications services, providing access to a range of carriers and providing cheaper prices and better services. We want to see the introduction of new technologies, when they become available, right across this country. The proposed programs announced today are going to go a long way to seeing that happen. We, as a government, are very much focused on delivering the very best telecommunication services for the people of Australia.

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I think we have just heard a speech in favour of the retention of part-government ownership in Telstra! Contrary to what some of the Labor speakers have said, I believe that the government, as a partial owner of Telstra, has introduced some good initiatives. I think that has been driven by the political imperative-the capacity and the ability of members of parliament to drive some of the issues, particularly in regional Australia, to some degree of fruition and to create some political pressure. Regrettably, given the decision of today, that pressure will be taken off. If you listened to the Treasurer and the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry yesterday-and others from the government side-you would have heard them say that they recognise that, for a fully privathis tised operation to exist, there has to be a profit imperative, not a service imperative, for those in remote and rural areas. I think it is a very sad day for country Australia and a very sad day for this parliament. Although members of the government, particularly the National Party, are very excited about this initiative, there is not one member of the National Party in this chamber-other than you, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, and you are here in an official capacity. So quite obviously those members are fully aware that they have been run over by the Liberal bus on this decision. They are in disgrace in their electorates. They are in disgrace in Australia generally, with over 70 per cent of people not wanting this to happen. This is the ‘no excuses' parliament. There is no excuse for poor regional policy any more. You cannot blame the Greens or the Democrats for poor policy in the Senate. If the Senate takes this decision to alienate rural and regional Australia from the most important piece of infrastructure that exists-a piece of infrastructure that has the capacity to negate distances being a disadvantage for people living in Australia-it will be on the heads of the National Party. I noticed that the messiah of the nation last week, Senator Barnaby Joyce, has suddenly turned into the Judas goat of Queensland. He has come into the parliament and made wild claims about opposing the sale. He received my admiration for doing that because I thought: ‘Maybe for once there is a member of this party who will actually stand up for what the constituents in rural Australia are saying. Maybe for once there is a person who is prepared to stand up.' He did stand up for a little while, but he sat down again today. I think that is a real shame for the people of Queensland. It is a real shame, probably, for the individual. It is a great shame for nation that he has not stayed firm on this issue. I encourage him to rethink his position. But, Senator Joyce, do not go around this parliament saying, ‘I don't agree with the sale of Telstra but I had to accept something because Senator Murray from the Democrats or Senator Fielding from the Family First Party would vote for it.' Do not discredit those individuals to try and garner some sort of impression that you have done a good deal. This is a disgraceful deal. One thing that we have found out today is what is up to scratch. This term ‘up to scratch' has fascinated me for years. Senator Joyce and others have said that they will relate to experts in terms of what is required. The expert was down here last week: the new CEO of Telstra. He made a point that there had been a $5 billion underinvestment. There had been far too much of a focus on sale rather than service. He made the point that $5 billion is required. The minister has brushed that aside, the government has brushed that aside, Barnaby Joyce has brushed that aside and the National Party has brushed that aside. They have said, ‘You can have $1 billion now or over the next few years to look after the underinvestment that has been in place in current infrastructure and you can have the interest off this $2 billion fund.' In the Leader of the National Party's words, the interest is about $100 million a year, which is $25 million a year less than what they have spent over the last eight, so it is a reduction in government spending in terms of ongoing future proofing of the instrumentality. If we assume that the CEO knows something about telecommunications, he believes that $5 billion would need to be invested immediately to bring it up to scratch. If we look at how that is going to come about now, it will take 40 years to get Telstra up to scratch in 2005. There is the $1 billion that they are giving now and the other $4 billion will come over 40 years at $100 million a year. That is what this parliament is looking at doing. That is what the National Party and other country members in this parliament are prepared to do to their constituency. We will be up to scratch in 40 years time. That is assuming that the $5 billion underinvestment is true. But the CEO is the closest expert and should be the closest expert in terms of the decision-making process. So all of those who have stood up in here and said, ‘We won't do anything until it's up to scratch,' should come back in 40 years time-and the line in the sand is 2005. I think that is the disgrace- ringful act that is being perpetrated on the people of Australia and regional Australia today. No wonder there is not a member of the National Party in this room. No wonder they are not boasting about it, because they have been done over like a dinner. I have been speaking to the Liberals and they are laughing at this. This is a far better deal than they ever contemplated. They have got the sale. Mr Wilkie interjecting

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Swan may wish to speak in a minute.

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: They are going to spend $25 million less a year in terms of the Future Fund and this mythical billion that is going to bring things up to scratch. I am proud to vote against this and I am proud to speak against it, because the people of Australia do not want it to happen and it should not happen. The National Party have proven to me today that they are not only prepared to offer bribes; they are prepared to accept bribes and that is an absolute disgrace.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for New England will withdraw that inference.

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for New England will not withdraw that inference, Mr Deputy Speaker.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I name the member for New England. Mr Bevis- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: There is no point of order. I name the member for New England. Mr Bevis-I am entitled to rise on a point of order. Mr Deputy Speaker, as I am sure you are well aware, comments that may be unparliamentary when referring to an individual are not unparliamentary when refer

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Brisbane would be well aware that when a member is asked to withdraw the comment they will withdraw it. The member for Brisbane will resume his seat. Mr Bevis-Are you going to rule on the point of order?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I said the member for Brisbane will resume his seat immediately. I will deal with the member for New England and then I will deal with the member for Brisbane. I name the member for New England.

Speaker: Ms LEY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Farrer-Parliamentary Secretary (Children and Youth Affairs)) (4.18 pm)-I move: That the member for New England be suspended from the service of the House. A division having been called and the bells being rung Mr Bevis- Mr Deputy Speaker, I raised a point of order and I have not heard any determination.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Brisbane is well aware that when a member is asked to withdraw a comment they will withdraw the comment without any debate. Mr Bevis-What is the ruling on my point of order?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have just told the member for Brisbane, when a member is asked by the chair to withdraw a comment the member will withdraw the comment without debate. Mr Bevis-I understand the standing order

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: This is not a debate. The member for Brisbane has the point of order. Mr Bevis-But I do not have a ruling on it, Mr Deputy Speaker. That is the point I am seeking.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: If the member for Brisbane wants to be dealt with after this, I will deal with him. Mr Bevis-I seek your guidance as to at what point I get an answer to my

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Brisbane has the answer, and it is not a debate. Mr Fitzgibbon- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I seek clarification of Kelly, J.M. the ruling you have just made on the member for Brisbane's intervention. Can I suggest to you that the implication of that ruling is that

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Hunter will come to his point of order. Mr Fitzgibbon-Can I suggest, Mr Deputy Speaker, the implication of that ruling is that you have now set a new precedent and that members of this parliament can now offend the collective.
