Vaile, M.A.J. Vale, D.S. Vasta, R. Wakelin, B.H. Washer, M.J. Wood, J. * denotes teller Question negatived. Ms Gillard- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It is looking at confirmation and clarification of your last ruling. I will take you to House of Representatives Practice, page 502.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: If the member for Lalor wishes me to explain where I rely on my ruling, I will give her the ruling. I rely on standing order 90, which is about improper imputations. If she wants the precedent, it is the precedent of Speaker Snedden, who ruled on whether it could be the individual or the collective. Ms Gillard-Precisely. I was taking you to the ruling of Speaker

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: The member for Lalor cannot debate a point of order. Ms Gillard-If I could be allowed to state it, I think it would clarify the matter. My point of order is as follows: the ruling Speaker Snedden on page 502 does not seem to me to extend as far as you have used it today.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: If the member for Lalor wishes to take it up with the SpeakerMs Gillard-May I clarify my point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, so this exchange can be useful?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: If the member for Lalor wishes to take it up with the Speaker, she may. Ms Gillard-I am taking it up with you, Mr Deputy Speaker, because it is your ruling. Is it your ruling that you have enlarged Speaker Snedden's ruling to apply to words not contained in that ruling? If so, can you explain to me why it was that the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education was not named yesterday for using terms inappropriately? How is that consistent?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: I explained to the member for Lalor that I relied upon standing order 90 and, as a precedent, I relied upon Speaker Snedden's ruling. If she disagrees with that, she can take it up with the Speaker and the Speaker will give a defi- 2005 nition. Ms Gillard- Mr Deputy Speaker, can I suggest

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: Is this a point of order? Ms Gillard-Yes, it is a point of order.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: What is the point of order? Ms Gillard-Given that you have just said that this matter ought to be taken up with the Speaker, can I suggest that you voluntarily remove yourself from the chair so the Speaker can take it?

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: The member of for Lalor will resume her seat. I will now present the report of the Selection Committee relating to consideration of committee and delegation reports and private members' business.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: NOES
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: NOES
text: Order! I dealt with the point of order of the member for Lalor, and the member for Brisbane was exactly the same. NA Selection Committee Report

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I present the report of the Selection Committee relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private members' business on Monday, 5 September 2005. The report will be printed in today's Hansard and the items accorded priority for debate will be published in the Notice Paper for the next sitting. The report read as followsReport relating to the consideration of committee and delegation reports and private Members' business on Monday, 5 September Pursuant to standing order 222, the Selection Committee has determined the order of precedence and times to be allotted for consideration of committee and delegation reports and private Members' business on Monday, 5 September 2005. The order of precedence and the allotments of time determined by the Committee are as follows: NA NA Presentation and statements 1 AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY NA NA NA Report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the Russian Federation and public, 17 April to 1 May 2005 The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made - all statements to conclude by 12.35 p.m. Speech time limits Each Member - 5 minutes. [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 1 x 5 mins] 2 JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE NA Report of the inspections of Baxter Immigration Detention Facility and Port Augusta Residential Housing Project, April 2005 The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made - all statements to conclude by 12.50 p.m. Speech time limits Each Member - 5 minutes. [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 3 x 5 mins] 3 JOINT PARLIAMENTARY NA NA Property investment advice: Safe as houses? Timeshare - The price of leisure The Committee determined that statements on these two reports may be made - all statements to conclude by 1.05 p.m. Speech time limits Each Member - 5 minutes. [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 3 x 5 mins] 4 PARLIAMENTARY NA NA The trafficking of women for sexual servitude Supplementary report The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made - all statements to conRUSSIAN clude by 1.10 p.m. ITALIAN Speech time limits Each Member - 5 minutes. [Minimum number of proposed Members the Italian Respeaking = 1 x 5 mins] 5 PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE ON ASIO, ASIS AND DSD Review of the listing of four terrorist organisations The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made - all statements to conclude by 1.20 p.m. Speech time limits Each Member - 5 minutes. [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 2 x 5 mins] 6 JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE NA NA Antarctica: Australia's pristine frontier No speaking time allotted. PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS Order of precedence Notices 1 Mr Katter to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Fuel Quality Standards Act 2000. (Fuel Quality Standards (Renewable Content of Motor Vehicle Fuel) Amendment Bill 2005) (Notice given 2 June 2005.) Presenter may speak for a period not exceeding 5 minutes - pursuant to standing order 41. 2 Mr Albanese to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Act 1999. (Avoiding Dangerous Climate Change (Climate Change Trigger) Bill 2005) (Notice given 10 August 2005.) Presenter may speak for a period not exceedJOINT ing 5 minutes - pursuant to standing order 41. 3 Mr Kerr to present a Bill for an Act to establish the Parliamentary (Judicial Behaviour or Incapacity) Commission. (Parliamentary (Judicial Behaviour or Incapacity) Commission Bill 2005) (Notice given 16 August 2005.) Presenter may speak for a period not exceeding 5 minutes - pursuant to standing order 41. 4 Mr Kelvin Thomson to present a Bill for an Act to regulate government advertising, and for related purposes. (Government Advertising (Prohibiting use of taxpayers' money on party political advertising) Bill 2005) (Notice given 16 August 2005.) Presenter may speak for a period not exceeding 5 minutes - pursuant to standing order 41. 5 Mr Bartlett to move: That this House: (1) recognises: (a) the extent and gravity of world poverty and the urgency of tackling this situation; and (b) that the most impoverished countries cannot escape the cycle of poverty without assistance; (2) acknowledges recent efforts by the Australian Government including increases in the Australian aid budget; (3) supports the Millenium Development Goals and world efforts to have world poverty by 2015; and (4) urges the Australian Government to continue to work towards the achievement of those goals. Time allotted - 30 minutes. Speech time limits Mover of motion - 5 minutes. First Opposition Member speaking - 5 minutes. Other Members - 5 minutes each. [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 6 x 5 mins] The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day. 6 Mr Martin Ferguson to move: That this House: (1) expresses its opposition to major retail chains such as Woolworths and Coles being able to open pharmacies in supermarkets; and (2) reaffirms its support for community pharmacies and in doing so recognises that the extension of pharmacies to major retail supermarkets will: (a) lead to the closure of many community pharmacies, the majority of whom are hard working small businesses; (b) lead to the loss of jobs amongst the 30,000 assistants currently employed in community pharmacies; (c) put at risk the 80 million free services provided by community pharmacies to the Australian community, many of whom cannot afford the cost of going to the doctor due to the decline in bulk billing, and (d) lead to the reduction in training and career opportunities for people who have chosen pharmacy as their career. (Notice given 9 August 2005.) Time allotted - remaining private Members' business time. Speech time limits Mover of motion - 5 minutes. First Government Member speaking - 5 minutes. Other Members - 5 minutes each. [Minimum number of proposed Members speaking = 6 x 5 mins] The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day. Public Works Committee Reports

Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Title: EXTERNAL TERRITORIES
text: On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the 11th, 12th, 13th, 14th and 15th reports for 2005 of the committee relating to: Holsworthy program-special operations working accommodation and base redevelopment stage 1; proposed CSIRO entomology bioscience laboratory at Black Mountain, Canberra; operational upgrade of Darwin detention facility, Berrimah, Northern Territory; upgrade patrol boat facilities, HMAS Coonawarra, Darwin; and redevelopment of Kokoda Barracks, Canungra, Queensland. Ordered that the reports be made parliamentary papers.

Speaker: Mrs MOYLAN
Title: EXTERNAL TERRITORIES
text: by leave-The committee's 11th report of 2005 addresses the construction of working accommodation for special operations forces and stage 1 of the redevelopment of Holsworthy Barracks, New South Wales. The proposed works will facilitate the establishment of the Army's full time commando capability, based upon the 4th Battalion, the Royal Australian Regiment (Commando); the Tactical Assault Group (East) becoming an organic element of the 4th Battalion, the Royal Australian Regiment (Commando); the Incident Response Regiment; Special Operations Combat Services Support Company; and the first stage of the redevelopment of Holsworthy Barracks. Having investigated the proposal, the committee is satisfied that the works will improve amenity for and operational efficiency of the important Army units accommodated at Holsworthy. The committee therefore recommends that the works proceed at the estimated cost of $207.7 million. The committee's 12th report of 2005 examines the proposed construction of a new entomology bioscience laboratory at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's (CSIRO's) Black Mountain campus in the ACT. The CSIRO reported that the Division of Entomology currently conducts scientific research in buildings that range in age from 32 to 76 years old. These buildings: do not meet contemporary research standards; have, in some instances, structural constraints which prevent them being refurbished to a level commensurate with current and evolving laboratory standards; do not meet current OH&S of standards; and cannot accommodate anticipated division growth. To redress these deficiencies, the CSIRO proposes to: construct a new two-storey, 2,313 square metre entomology bioscience laboratory; refurbish two existing buildings; construct covered walkways to link the new and existing buildings; and carry out associated site works and landscaping, including demolition of redundant buildings and sheds. Noting that some of the redundant buildings contain asbestos, the committee recommends that the CSIRO take all necessary steps to identify and ensure the safe removal and disposal of hazardous materials from the site. The committee also recommends that the CSIRO continues discussion with the National Capital Authority to resolve any outstanding design issues. Having considered the proposal in detail, members are satisfied that the works should proceed at the estimated cost of $12.7 million. The committee's 13th report of 2005 deals with a proposal by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, DIMIA, to carry out an operational upgrade of the detention facility at Berrimah, Northern Territory, at an estimated cost of $8.21 million. The primary purpose of the proposed works is to establish a safe and secure land based detention facility for illegal foreign fishers apprehended in Australia's northern waters. The department reported that illegal foreign fishing in Australia's northern waters has been increasing in recent years and that current boat based detention arrangements have proven unmanageable. It is envisaged that, in addition to illegal foreign fishers, the facility will accommodate Northern Territory immigration compliance cases and unauthorised air arrivals, some of whom the department told us would be women and children. The committee notes that the department's proposal contains a significant number of undetermined factors which may be expected to impact upon the project cost. Whilst cognisant of the difficulties associated with estimating project budgets under modern procurement arrangements, the committee requests that agencies supply the most robust and comprehensive costs available in order that the committee can fulfil its statutory as a scrutineer of public expenditure. The committee therefore recommends that DIMIA supply regular updates on expenditure throughout the course of the project. Having viewed both the existing facilities at the Berrimah detention centre and the plans for the upgrade, the committee remains unconvinced that the proposed family area represents the best use of available space or provides a reasonable level of amenity or security for detainees. Despite the recent changes to the government's policy in relation to the detention of families with children, the department explained that it may be necessary to hold people for a very short period of time for initial assessment. Given the inadequacy and inappropriateness of the proposed family area, the committee recommends that families including women and children are not detained at the facility. In the event that there is a demonstrated need for the short-term detention of families at the facility, the committee recommends that, in order to ensure appropriate provision of security-particularly separation from the large number of fishers that may be held at the centre-amenity and space for families, women and children, the department should better utilise the space available. The family area should be enlarged and should provide appropriate separation of all facilities, which is a major security issue, adequate indoor recreation space and a secure outdoor area of a suitable size to accommodate play equipment relocated from the existing large, grassed recreation area. The committee hopes that there will not be an occasion to keep families with children in this particular facility. The committee also wishes to ensure the reliability of DIMIA's project delivery strategy and recommends that the department supply the committee with an update on the chosen delivery methodology and the applirole cation of Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines to this process, when this information becomes available. Further, in the interest of transparency and good community relations, the committee recommends that DIMIA consult with the local community and with relevant Northern Territory government agencies in respect of the proposed works. In particular, the committee wishes DIMIA to consult with the office of the Northern Territory Chief Minister to find an appropriate name for the facility. Having given careful consideration to the proposal, the committee recommends that the works proceed at the estimated cost of $8.21 million. A further referral from the Department of Defence, namely the upgrade of patrol boat facilities at HMAS Coonawarra, Darwin, forms the subject of the committee's 14th report of 2005. The upgraded facilities, estimated to cost $19.17 million, will facilitate the introduction into service of the Armidale class patrol boat and will also provide a new facility for the Darwin Port Services Organisation. The committee notes Defence's efforts to minimise the environmental impacts of the proposed works and, in respect of any future dredging activities, recommends that the department maintain close consultation with the Northern Territory Department of Lands, Planning and Environment to ensure minimisation of damage to the marine environment. In view of the importance of fire protection and evacuation measures, the committee recommends that Defence supply it with details of the fire protection system proposed for the standby crew and port services organisation building, including any departures from the requirements of the Building Code of Australia, when these have been determined. The committee is satisfied with the evidence supplied by Defence and is happy for the works to proceed at the estimated cost of $19.17 million. The 15th report of 2005 presents the committee's findings in relation to the proposed redevelopment of Kokoda Barracks at Canungra, Queensland, for the Department of Defence. The purpose of the proposed work is to provide the working and domestic accommodation, and engineering services infrastructure required, for the ongoing delivery of effective training at the Canungra Military Training Area. The redevelopment entails: correction of working and training accommodation deficiencies; rationalisation of messing facilities; improvements to living-in accommodation for trainees; upgrade of the engineering services infrastructure; and disposal of redundant, high-maintenance facilities. During its inquiry, the committee investigated a range of barracks services; the design of the proposed new facilities; the removal of asbestos; heritage issues; and traffic management. The committee recommends that the works proceed at the estimated cost of $86.7 million and requests that Defence continue consultation with the Department of the Environment and Heritage regarding any heritage issues that may arise from the redevelopment project. These reports examine works representing some $336.28 million worth of Commonwealth expenditure. It has been a very heavy workload for the committee secretariat. I would like to take this opportunity to thank my committee colleagues and to thank Hansard and our committee secretariat for helping to facilitate this work in a timely manner. I commend the reports to the House.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: EXTERNAL TERRITORIES
text: Order! Just before proceeding and giving the call to the member for Gorton, the chair indicates to the minister at the table, the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads-I know that he might not have been directly involved-that for a period that might have been described as lengthy by some there was no member of the executive at the table. Whilst I do not think that this afternoon would have been exactly the time to have directly and immediately acted upon that, the chair notes that. I ask the minister, especially with his experience as the Chief Government Whip, if he could assist the House by ensuring that others that are on the roster are in the chamber.

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Title: EXTERNAL TERRITORIES
text: by leave-I want to supplement the comments made by the member for Pearce in relation to these public worksnamely, the Holsworthy program special operations working accommodation and base redevelopment stage 1; the proposed CSIRO entomology bioscience laboratory at Black Mountain, Canberra; the operational upgrade at Darwin detention facility, Berrimah; the upgrade of patrol boat facilities at HMAS Coonawarra, Darwin; and the redevelopment of Kokoda Barracks, Canungra, Queensland. As the chair of the committee has indicated, the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works has an enormous workload. The committee members share the workload well. Indeed, the work is made that much easier as a result of the diligence and professionalism of the secretariat of the committee. I would like to express particular appreciation for their work. I support the comments made by the member for Pearce in relation to these five works. In particular, I would like to emphasise in relation to the operational upgrade of the Darwin Detention Facility Berrimah the need for DIMIA to take the committee's concerns on board in relation to what we are to do for children and families if we find them in a position to be enclosed behind fencesgiven, as I understand it, the shift in government policy in that regard. We have made it clear that we do not consider it appropriate for families and children to be placed in that situation. We hope that there is a capacity for that never to happen. The department has raised the point that there may be occasions on which emergencies require such detention, but we think that should be unnecessary. Indeed, we ask the department and the minister to look at that matter with a view to ensuring that that is avoided at all costs. Finally, in relation to that project, I again ask the department to make contact with the Northern Territory government. They have raised a concern that they do not want the detention centre in Darwin to be entitled ‘Darwin Detention Centre'. There are good reasons for the name change, we accept, without going through the reasons now. We understand why there is the need to change the name. However, committee members accepted the view that there is no need to call a detention centre ‘Darwin Detention Centre'. The Chief Minister and the Northern Territory government believed it was not in the interests of people residing in Darwin, in the Northern Territory. Other than the Perth detention centre, I think it is true to say all other centres in capital cities-Villawood, Maribyrnong-are not named after the city in which they reside. Therefore we hope that the department are able to consider the recommendations of the Public Works Committee in light of the request made by the Northern Territory government to ensure that that centre is not named the ‘Darwin Detention Centre'. Treaties Committee Report

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: EXTERNAL TERRITORIES
text: On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties I present the committee's report, incorporating a dissenting report, entitled: Report 66-Treaties tabled on 7 December 2004 (4), 15 March and 11 May 2005, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee. Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: EXTERNAL TERRITORIES
text: by leave-Report 66 contains the findings and recommendations of the review conducted by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties of nine treaty actions tabled in parliament on 7 December 2004, 15 March 2005 and 11 May 2005. The treaty actions relate to the matters identified in the title of the report. I will comment on a selection of the treaty actions considered. The United Nations Convention against Corruption is a multilateral agreement designed to enhance international efforts to combat corruption. Although no changes to Commonwealth legislation are required to implement Australia's obligations under UNCAC, the committee raised two issues with this treaty. One issue, relating to whether a provision of the treaty is mandatory, discretionary or optional, changes the extent of the Commonwealth's power to legislate for it. The major issue the committee that considered was the degree to which this treaty confers additional jurisdiction on the Commonwealth through the use of the external affairs power under section 51(xxix) of the Constitution. The committee considers that the external affairs power is not always an ideal head of power from which to legislate, particularly where the treaty has the potential to significantly impact on the states and territories. Evidence to the committee suggested that the use of the external affairs power is limited to some extent by the Melbourne Corporation doctrine-that is, it is unlikely that the Commonwealth could enact legislation which relates to corrupt conduct of members of state parliaments, state executives and state courts in the discharge of their functions as state officials. Even so, the committee has made two recommendations asking the Attorney-General to advise the committee that there is no intention to use the external affairs power and UNCAC to pass legislation not foreshadowed in the NIA. The amendments to the SingaporeAustralia Free Trade Agreement add a further two universities-Murdoch University and the University of Tasmania-to the list of Australian universities whose graduates are recognised for admission as qualified lawyers in Singapore. As a South Australian, I am pleased to see Flinders University on the list of 10 and I look forward to the day that the University of Adelaide is added. Since 1995, Singapore armed forces have used the Shoalwater Bay training area. The committee supports the agreement between Australia and Singapore, which will allow the continued use of the Shoalwater Bay training area by the Singapore armed forces for five years from 31 December 2004. Report 66 also recommends the entry into force of a treaty between Australia and New Zealand that defines maritime boundaries between our two countries. This treaty serves as a model for bilateral cooperation on maritime boundaries. Lastly, the committee has recommended that a treaty which establishes a permanent and independent secretariat to administer the Antarctic Treaty consultation meeting enter into force. Australia has a large territorial claim and an extensive research program in Antarctica. The secretariat will be in Buenos Aires, Argentina. In conclusion, the committee believes it is in Australia's national interest for the nine treaties considered in report 66 to be ratified. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: Mr WILKIE
Title: EXTERNAL TERRITORIES
text: by leave-The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties' review included treaty actions from a diverse range of subject areas. Similarly to previous reviews, the committee's findings were based on an examination of the benefits to Australia of each treaty action. This included examining each of the nine treaty actions with regard to their impact on the political, diplomatic, security, economic and social ties between Australia and the treaty parties. Of particular interest in this batch of treaties is the United Nations Convention against Corruption. I will not talk about each of the treaty actions, because I thought I would complement the comments that the chair has already made. The United Nations Convention against Corruption will provide for a number of measures relating to corruption prevention and criminalisation, international cooperation in combating corruption, asset recovery, training and technical assistance and the establishment of a conference of the parties to the convention. In addition to recommending that binding treaty action be taken, the committee made two other recommendations. These recommendations relate to issues surrounding the Australian government's potential use of its external powers to override the will of the states and territories where implementation of this treaty is concerned. These recommendations are particularly important as the committee has encountered a similar situation with other treaties. Another treaty of interest is one that establish and define the exclusive economic zone and continental shelf boundaries between Australia and New Zealand in the Tasman Sea and adjacent areas of the southwestern Pacific Ocean. There are currently no agreed maritime boundaries between the countries, and I welcome this treaty, which will sort this matter out. I am particularly disappointed, though, that it would appear that many of the criteria used to determine these particular boundaries were not used in the case of East Timor. It was put to us by the department that we had to look at each case on its merit. I believe that some of the criteria that were used in determining the boundaries between Australia and New Zealand could in fact have been used when we were looking at the East Timor-Australia delineation. The Agreement on Cooperation in the Fields of Energy and Mineral Resources with the Republic of Korea will provide a framework to pursue areas of mutual benefit and interest in relation to energy and mineral products. The agreement includes provisions on the exchange of energy and mineral resources information; the promotion and facilitation of technical cooperation in the fields of energy and mineral resources; cooperation and facilitation of bilateral trade and investment in energy and mineral resources, including value added products and services; and the development and implementation of greenhouse gas mitigation projects in the context of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The final treaty I would like to make tion of is the Mutual Recognition Agreement on Conformity Assessment in relation to Medicines Goods Manufacturing Practice Inspection and Certification with Canada. The treaty will provide for reciprocal recognition of goods manufacturing practice certificates of medicines between Australia and will Canada. Under the current pharmaceutical inspection scheme, countries are not legally bound to supply information nor to do so in any specified time period. The treaty would afford certainty to Australian exporters of medicinal products and eliminate uncertainty and any delays or costs associated with retesting batches of medicines on import into Canada. I would like to comment on the agreement between Australia and Singapore on the use of the Shoalwater Bay training facility. I commend this particular move, having been to Shoalwater Bay and seen what is on offer there and the sorts of facilities that are being built by our partners. I think they are great facilities and it is a great treaty. I commend that to the House also. I would also like to send thanks to those who put forward submissions in relation to these matters and to the committee secretariat who have, once again, done a fantastic job.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: EXTERNAL TERRITORIES
text: I move: That the House take note of the report. I seek leave to continue my remarks later. Leave granted; debate adjourned. Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation Committee Report

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: EXTERNAL TERRITORIES
text: On behalf of the Standing Committee on Employment, Workplace Relations and Workforce Participation I present the committee's report, incorporating a dissenting report, entitled Making it work: inquiry into independmen- ent contracting and labour hire arrangements, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee. Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: EXTERNAL TERRITORIES
text: by leave-I am pleased to present this report on independent contracting and labour hire arrangements. This inquiry was conducted at a time of increasing debate on the conditions of Australian workers, with possible changes to federal workplace relations legislation affecting the coverage of state legislation, including proposals to develop legislation to support independent contractors. In a highly competitive global market, flexibility and response times are crucial. As a result, demand from companies for labour hire and contractor services has increased over the last 20 years. Currently, over 10 per cent of the work force identify themselves as being independent contractors and nearly four per cent identify themselves as labour hire workers. These types of working arrangements are found across a wide variety of industries. Supporting labour hire and contracting arrangements is essential for a number of reasons. These include: meeting shortages of labour or fluctuating demands across industries and occupations; providing avenues for mature age workers to remain in the work force and transition employment opportunities for those seeking to enter the workforce; achieving efficiencies that enable us to compete in the global marketplace; and offering a range of working arrangements that may provide different lifestyle and remuneration benefits from those offered through direct employment options. It has been a challenging task for the committee to examine current state and federal workplace relations systems to identify strategies that provide a balance of freedoms and protections-and to do so with greater consistency across Australia. There are 16 recommendations included in the report, and they are: to address the occupational health and safety of labour hire workers and independent contractors; to improve access to skill development and training for labour hire workers; to establish a voluntary code of practice for the labour hire industry; to create greater consistency across federal, state and territory legislation in differentiating between independent contractors and employees; to improve access to information to outline the rights and responsibilities of independent contractors; to regulate independent contractors under commercial law; and to improve access to different dispute resolution procedures for independent contractors. The committee investigated whether labour hire and contracting arrangements are, in some instances, being used to evade responsibilities, particularly in the areas of occupational health and safety and employee entitlements. The committee does not condone the creation of artificial structures to avoid regulatory compliance by host businesses, labour hire agencies or contractors and it does not condone the creation of artificial independent contracting arrangements to avoid the incumbent responsibilities of an employee-employer relationship. Key to curbing possible sham arrangements is the national need for greater clarity and consistency in distinguishing between an employee and an independent contractor. The committee has opted for a pragmatic strategy-one that combines existing national approaches to achieve an Australia-wide national outcome. Essentially the strategies recommended are to provide assistance for establishing genuine arrangements and to reduce opportunities for establishing artificial arrangements that seek to avoid responsibilities. Considering independent contractors within commercial relationships provides the appropriate framework for supporting and developing independent contractors as businesses. It is important that these legitimate business relationships and choices are honoured and are not subject to excessive protectionist regulation. Improved access to relevant information on rights and responsibilities is key to ing there is informed choice in selecting working arrangements. Additionally, when a dispute arises regarding a contract for services, more accessible, affordable resolution procedures are necessary, such as use of the Federal Magistrates Court. Labour hire and independent contracting arrangements are a vital element of the Australian work force. A balanced approach of flexibility and protections has been sought to recognise the needs of labour hire agencies, workers, employers, principal contractors and independent contractors. Once again the members of the committee demonstrated considerable commitment to working together to report in a reasonably short time. I thank the deputy chair, the member for Gorton, and other members of the committee for their cooperation and dedication to the inquiry. While there has been dissent on party lines on some of the recommendations, overall there is unified support for the majority of the report. I also take this opportunity to thank the inquiry secretariat for their counsel, assistance and patience throughout the processparticularly Dr Anna Dacre, Alison Childs and their very hard working team. In conclusion, I would like to thank the many individuals and organisations who provided evidence to this inquiry through submissions or by appearing before the committee. The strategies outlined in this report are designed to make labour hire and independent contracting arrangements work for Australians and for Australian businesses. Together these strategies work to make a competitive Australia, offering a range of working arrangements to suit industry, occupation, employer and worker requirements. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Title: EXTERNAL TERRITORIES
text: by leave-I rise to add to the comments made by the member for Deakin. Firstly, I would like to say that there was indeed a very short time frame for the committee and great regard was given to the pressures of time. It is true to say that therefore the committee members and the secretariat worked expeditiously to arrive at this outcome. But this afternoon I have to emphasise the concerns raised in the dissenting report. It is true to say that good work was done, as has already been expressed by the member for Deakin, the chair of the committee. Indeed, there was goodwill shown by committee members. However, it is important to note that Making it work: inquiry into independent contracting and labour hire arrangements made a total of 16 recommendations, of which nine were agreed to unanimously. A dissenting report provided alternatives to seven of the recommendations and made seven additional recommendations for the government to consider. It is the view of the dissenting members that, in some respects, the committee missed a golden opportunity to clear up the growing confusion as to who is an employee and who is a genuine contractor in the Australian work force. The committee's report, tabled today, also failed to provide any real clarification regarding the rights and responsibilities of labour hire agencies, employees and host employers. The report's findings, we argue, were prejudiced by the interference of the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, who chose to release his own paper and set up his own closed inquiry on the same matter soon after referring it to the committee. In our view, the minister's disregard for the parliamentary committee process had an adverse influence upon the findings of the committee. In our view, the minister treated the parliamentary process with contempt. Having referred the matter to the committee in the first place, the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations then chose to pre-empt the committee's findings and prejudice its deliberations by releasing a per with loaded assertions and opinions and by establishing his own closed inquiry on the same matter. This behaviour was another example of the government's abuse of parliamentary process and, in the view of the dissenting members, may have adversely affected the committee's recommendations. It was, in our view, an attempt to sideline parliamentary committee and influence the views of, in particular, government members of the committee. I now turn to the substantive matters raised in evidence given to the committee, starting with disguised forms of employment. Another way to expose workers to unfairness is to call them ‘contractors' and take away their employee entitlements. The dissenting report sought to clarify the delineation between an employee and a genuine independent contractor. The committee heard comprehensive and compelling evidence of sham arrangements and forms of disguised employment but, unfortunately, failed to recommend any concrete solutions to the growing problems of confusion and exploitation. Evidence showed that many workers were being forced to work as so-called independent contractors in order to avoid taxation and traditional employer responsibilities such as the payment of superannuation contributions and workers compensation insurance premiums. The evidence highlighted an absence of taxation laws to properly distinguish employees from independent contractors for the purpose of collecting the nation's revenue. Some witnesses asserted that the amount of revenue lost as a result runs into billions of dollars each year. Evidence given by Treasury underlined the inability of the Commonwealth to determine the extent of tax avoidance by employees wrongfully described as ‘contractors'. Although the personal services income legislation sought to prevent tax pa- avoidance, its effectiveness is unknown because, as confirmed by Treasury, well over 99.9 per cent of tax claims in this area are self-assessed. It is therefore not known whether these provisions, weak as they are, are being enforced properly. The extraordinarily high proportion of self-assessing PSI applicants fails to instil in the dissenting the members any confidence that the current system is an effective means of distinguishing genuine independent contractors from employees. The committee was concerned by the significant evidence highlighting the extraordinary growth of labour hire employment in the last 15 years. All committee members accepted the possible benefits of labour hire employment, but the report failed to recognise the intrinsic difficulties with labour hire arrangements. In particular, the committee failed to address the extremely high proportion of labour hire workers who are precariously employed. The rate of casualisation amongst labour hire employees exceeds 75 per cent, or more than three times the work force average. The committee received evidence of labour hire employees working for more than 10 years and still being described as casuals. The report failed to propose any relief from indefinitely being precariously employed. Furthermore, the committee received evidence that the triangular relationship involving labour hire agencies, host companies and labour hire workers has led to a blurring of legal obligations and entitlements in a number of areas such as occupational health and safety and return to work policies. Although the committee did identify some areas of concern, in our view it failed to provide solurepresent tions to the problem of assigning responsibilities in this area of work. Finally, I will describe in general terms the additional recommendations that the dissenting members felt the need to add as a result of a deficiency in the report. The senting members also recommended additional recommendations in order to fill the void left by the report. The recommendations include: proposals to prevent employees working for unreasonable periods as casuals, when they could appropriately be classified as permanents; shared occupational health and safety responsibilities for labour hire agencies and host employers; and the right for a contractor to choose their representative, whether that might be a trade union or not. Today I had the good fortune to meet with officials and members of the New South Wales branch of the Transport Workers Union. I also had the good fortune to listen to some of the members talk about their plight at a seminar held today at Parliament House. That was particularly relevant to this matter. I therefore think it is very important that government consider ensuring the right to be properly represented in the appropriate forums-which, the dissenting members would say, are the state and federal industrial commissions of this country-and that unions do not have limitations placed on their right to represent small businesses, which would be the case if the Trade Practices Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005 were to be enacted to limit those rights of representation. No government should remove the right for small businesses to choose a union as their agent-their representative. Therefore, in the dissenting report we make specific reference to removing that restriction and ensuring that the trade unions have the right-as every other body would have-to contractors or small businesses, if they so wish it. I thank the Transport Workers Union for waiting through many divisions and being here this afternoon to witness the tabling of the report. I thank them for their contribution dis- as a union. They presented many witnesses-many workers, not just officials. I think all committee members were impressed by the organisation's ability to provide evidence from people directly affected by the laws of this land, and we certainly wanted to respond to their concerns in the form of this report. I will finish by saying that an effort was made by all members to find common ground. We can say that nine of the 17 recommendations in the body of the report were agreed to. There are certainly some good policies that could be adopted by government if those recommendations were agreed to. I guess where we differ is that we say that the seven alternative recommendations made by the dissenting members and a further seven additional recommendations that are to be found in the body of the dissenting report the should be adopted by government to ensure that the contractors, employees, labour hire companies, principal contractors and the like know exactly where they stand in the law.

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: EXTERNAL TERRITORIES
text: I move: That the House take note of the report. I seek leave to continue my remarks later. Leave granted; debate adjourned. Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Title: CORPORATIONS AMENDMENT BILL
text: Hunter) (5.48 pm)Before being interrupted by question time, the MPI and subsequent interesting events, I was speaking to the Corporations Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005 and drawing on the extraordinary experience of a company known as Singleton Earthmoving Pty Ltd to make some important points which relate to the Corporations Law. I will briefly recap the story about this very viable company which was unnecessarily forced into administration by a person whom I would describe as a rogue liquidator. As a consequence, the main director of the company, Mr Bernard Wood, and all the unsecured creditors have lost their money. The only person who seems to have done well out of the decision to put the company into administration and consequently wind up the company is the liquidator himself, Mr Ariff. There is some good news at the end of all this. Mr Bernard Wood, a highly respectable character, has got back up on his feet and started a new company doing the same sort of work as he was doing previously. He has taken the resources of that company to attempt, at least, to pay back some of the money to the unsecured creditors. Of course, the original company is no longer a viable concern because, firstly, the liquidator seized all the plant and machinery of the company and, secondly, the liquidator is now owed up to $200,000 for his services. First Reading I am delighted to say that a week or so ago the creditors called another meeting to challenge the original decision of the creditors' meeting to pay this amount of remuneration to Mr Ariff and, indeed, to challenge the decision to wind up the company. Mr Bernard Wood and a number of creditors now claim that a Mr Gary Phillips, who apparently is the solicitor to Mr Ariff, was the person who either moved or seconded a number of these motions, including the motion to pay the remuneration to Mr Ariff, even though Mr Gary Phillips apparently had no status as a non-secured creditor and nor was he holding a proxy of an unsecured creditor.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: CORPORATIONS AMENDMENT BILL
text: Did he get part of the action?

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Title: CORPORATIONS AMENDMENT BILL
text: I will resist accepting the interjection from the member for Mitchell, as tempting as it is. In conclusion, I want to read part of a letter that Mr Wood sent to ASIC. A number of letters have been sent, but I just want to share this very quickly with the House. He says: Although I am a Director and the major unsecured creditor, this letter is in relation to me, with the advice of an experienced administrator, becoming the secured creditor by assuming the subrogation rights after paying out the National Bank. Rather than be paid ($276,000) from the administration I chose to have the unencumbered machinery to that value returned to me (which on October 10, 2004 the administrator seized without a court order). Nearly four months after becoming the secured creditor, hethat is, the administratorwill not release the machinery and refuses to reply to my correspondence. To date he has sold all encumbered plant, paid the financiers in full, kept the surplus along with the $290,000 debtor money collected. Not only will he not speak with me, but also the unsecured creditors. In addition, at the last creditors' meeting, December 17, 2004I should say that this letter is dated 18 April 2005where the main issue was to agree to his fees, he used a non-creditor or creditors' representative, a Mr Gary Phillips, to move a motion approving his  tor, convinced the other five who voted to pay the administrator and if they didn't the Supreme Court would approve the fees thereby incurring additional costs. In other words, Mr Ariff was threatening the unsecured creditors if they were not prepared to both back the motion to wind up the company and approve the remuneration for the administrator and subsequent liquidator. The letter continues: Speaking for all the unsecured creditors, is it possible for that December meeting to be deemed null and void due to an illegal vote? Hopefully Mr Wood's question has now been answered, given the most recent creditors' meeting held in Singleton only last week.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: CORPORATIONS AMENDMENT BILL
text: Do you seek leave to table that document?

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Title: CORPORATIONS AMENDMENT BILL
text: No, I do not think I need to, thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker; I have quoted extensively from the document. I am just amazed by this story. A good bloke had a good business that had been operating for 25 years, but a rogue director decided to seek to put the company into administration without any good reason. The administrator rolled up in Singleton in his Mercedes Benz and Zegna suit and recommended to a group of only partly informed, non-secured creditors that the company should be wound up. He seized all the possessions, rendering the company a nonviable concern. He has charged them a fortune to do so and, as a result, it is losers all around-other than for one Mr Ariff. I will close by repeating my call for the Treasurer to use his power under section 14 of the ASIC Act to intervene and instruct ASIC to revisit the issue if ASIC does not come up with any answers. I also call upon Mr Ariff to complete and make available the company's taxation returns for the year ending 2004 and 2005, which I am advised will show that there is no doubt that this company, Singleton Earthmoving, was very much a viable, ongoing concern.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: CORPORATIONS AMENDMENT BILL
text: I take an interest in a law that affects directors and their conduct, and I think that most Australians do in a cursory way, because they expect our company directors to be full of integrity. They expect them to be dynamic and good at their work and to make profits, but they do not expect them to make profits at the expense of others in the way we have just heard described and in the way in which Australians have observed in the HIH affair with Larry Adler and Mr Williams. The issue we are looking at today is a process whereby we are seeking to relieve directors of an inadvertent responsibility which was placed on them by an understanding of the Supreme Court in South Australia. It was not intended by the legislation when it was introduced, not intended by any comments of ministers at that time and not intended by this government or the opposition. The Australian Credit Management Law Bulletin is hardly bedtime reading, but, in this instance, it is interesting in that it clear explanation of why the government is moving to make the changes to the trustees' responsibility in a case where they are liable for the trust debt. This is the story. John ONEILL owned the shopping centre on the Belair Road in Kingswood, South Australia. Daroko Pty Ltd was a tenant, and Mr Kerry Hanel was the sole director of Daroko. Daroko was the trustee of the Daroko-(Quorum formed) I thank my colleagues for supporting me in such great numbers for this important debate on the Corporations Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005. I know they cannot wait till this bill passes the House so they can take it back to their electorates, filled with excitement about explaining to their electors and their constituents how significant this legislation is. In the field of corporate law, this is a significant bill. I have just described the way it became necessary for the government to proclaim this amendment, following the case in 2003 of Kerry Stirling Hanel and Anor v John ONEILL. A clause in the trust deed of the Daroko Unit Trust provided a comprehensive indemnity to Daroko, the company. The lease was for a term of five years from October 1998. It was due to expire on 30 September 2003. However, Hanel lost his Wendy's franchise business, so Daroko gave notice that it intended to vacate the premises on 30 June 2001. Before then, the Daroko Unit Trust-which had made a profit of $512,617-paid out all its fund to Hanel's personal trust, which left both Daroko and the Daroko Unit Trust without assets. In July 2002, ONEILL obtained judgment in the Adelaide Magistrates Court for $23,132.62, which he said were the costs associated with obtaining a tenant to replace Daroko. ONEILL sought to enforce this judgment but, in September, Hanel informed the court that, without any assets, Daroko was gives a unable to pay the judgment. ONEILL then applied for an order under section 197 of the Corporations Act. This section says in part: (1) A person who is a director of a corporation when it incurs a liability while acting, or purporting to act, as trustee, is liable to discharge the whole or a part of the liability if the corporation: (a) has not, and cannot, discharge the liability or that part of it; and (b) is not entitled to be fully indemnified against the liability out of trust assets. This is so, even if the trust does not have enough assets to indemnify the trustee. ONEILL argued that, as Hanel was the sole director of Daroko, Hanel was personally liable for the debt. ONEILL claimed the judgment debt of $23,132.62 plus a further $15,928.51 for a shortfall of rent. In December, ONEILL was awarded summary judgment against Hanel for the $23,132.62. Hanel appealed. Hanel argued that section 197 of the Corporations Act did not apply, as the trust deed contained an indemnity for the trustee against the assets of the trust. What we have here is a guy who has lost his franchise and wants to get out of the business. I understand that he had replacement lessees willing to come in and take over his lease, without any damage to the lessor. The lessor was slow in making up his mind whether to accept the new lessee. Time expired and there was a gap in the rent. The original lessee said: ‘I had this person ready to go, but you were not prepared to make the decision to accept them; therefore, I do not owe you that money. I haven't got anything to back you up.' The lessor said, ‘I'm going to get the money out of you one way or another. You have a trust but it is bare, so I am going after you personally because that is where the trust money finished up.' Hanel appealed against the decision that awarded the costs of $23,132.62 to the lessor, Mr ONEILL. Hanel argued that section 197 of the Corporations Act did not apply, as the trust deed contained an indemnity for the trustee against the assets of the trust. ONEILL argued that Hanel, as trustee, could not be indemnified because the Daroko Unit Trust did not have the assets to provide the indemnity, which was a situation in which Hanel had been involved. By a two to one majority, the Supreme Court agreed that section 197(1)(b) was to be interpreted so that a director could not escape personal liability merely by ensuring that a clause was written into the trust deed which could operate as a shield against personal liability, even though the director had caused the trust to be without funds to avoid paying the debt. The wash-up of it is that the accounting community, the credit management groups, the government and the opposition-in fact, all those who understand the responsibilities of directors-think this is an unusual and very broad decision that the court in South Australia has taken based on a single case. It is therefore necessary for the government to make an amendment to restore the situation to what it was previously. To clarify the act, we are moving the amendment today. I am very pleased that the government has sought to bring common sense into the situation. It recognises that we must have in Australia an impeccable set of directors running Australian businesses who have the confidence of the community-who are the investors-the confidence of their workers and the confidence of all the arms of government that are there to regulate the process. If we can achieve that, we will have great export sales and a vibrant business community, where people can invest with confidence and businesses can steam ahead and employ people-which in part is their purpose. I have great pleasure in supporting this amendment. I think it is sensible and within the philosophy of the government.  Secretary to the Treasurer) (6.06 pm)-in reply-I thank members for their participation in the second reading debate on the Corporations Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005. This bill will clarify the scope of the personal liability of directors of corporate trustees. It will address concerns that have arisen in the light of the recent decision in Hanel and ONEILL, which extended the personal liability of these directors under subsection 197(1) of the Corporations Act 2001. Prior to the December 2003 decision of the Full Court of the South Australian Supreme Court in Hanel, section 197and its predecessors had traditionally been interpreted as applying in very limited circumstances. These were where the corporate trustee's right to be indemnified out of trust assets was lost due to the trustee's conduct or where the terms of the trust deed were designed or could operate to deny creditors' access to trust assets to meet liabilities incurred by the corporation. (Quorum formed) Hanel and ONEILL significantly expanded the potential personal liability of directors of corporate trustees, from large superannuation trusts through to trading trusts running a small business. In essence, that decision effectively made directors of corporate trustees guarantors of trust liabilities. The proposed amendment contained in schedule 1 to this bill will, therefore, operate to restore the long standing interpretation of subsection 197(1). In addition to the clarification of subsection 197 of the Corporations Act, this bill also contains a technical amendment to clarify the operation of a transitional provision in the CLERP 9 legislation. This will ensure that the auditor independence provisions which applied before the enactment of that legislation continue to apply to financial years commencing prior to 1 July 2004. I note that the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee has commented on the retrospective commencement of the amendment in schedule 2 to this bill. The committee noted that the amendment did nothing more than preserve and give effect to the intention of the pre-CLERP 9 legislation. In concluding, I take this opportunity to note that this bill work to rebuild business confidence. Importantly, it will also preserve the application of the auditor independence provisions of the pre-CLERP 9 legislation. I commend the bill to the House. Question agreed to. Bill read a second time. Third Reading  Secretary to the Treasurer) (6.13 pm)-by leave-I move: That this bill be now read a third time. Question agreed to. Bill read a third time. NA SAFETY (COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 2005 Second Reading Debate resumed from 23 June, on motion by Mr Andrews: That this bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr MURPHY
Title: OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND
text: Mr Deputy Speaker Baldwin, our speaker is on his way to the chamber and he will be here very shortly. I am sure he will come rushing in the door. (Quorum formed)

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND
text: Labor oppose the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Amendment Bill 2005. We do so for the following reasons. Firstly, the bill proposes to remove the need for government agencies to negotiate occupational health and safety agreements with unions and employees, through the introduction of so-called management arrangements. Secondly, the bill will remove all references to ‘unions' and replace them with references to ‘employee representatives', defined as either a ‘regiswill tered organisation' or a ‘workplace staff association', which must now be invited into the workplace by an employee. Thirdly, the bill will require that an employee invite an employee representative to initiate an occupational health and safety investigation, where previously a union could make directly to Comcare such a request to investigate a workplace. Fourthly, employee representatives involved in developing occupational health and safety management arrangements must be issued with a certificate by the CEO of Comcare, valid only for a 12month period. Finally, the bill empowers employers to conduct the election of employee health and safety representatives, a role previously conducted by a union or a person specified by the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, which the government proposes to abolish through legislation passed through this House yesterday. Regrettably, Australia continues to have a poor record with respect to work related death, injury and illness. It is estimated that there are around 3,000 work related deaths in Australia each year-more than the national road toll. When one breaks this down, the true gravity of the situation becomes apparent. Nearly 450 of these work related deaths, an average of nearly 10 per week, are the result of a traumatic incident at work, including work related road deaths. A further 150 deaths occur while Australian employees travel to or from work, with another 200 people dying each year as a result of someone else's work activity. In 1996, National Occupational Health and Safety Commission researchers arrived at a conservative estimate that at least 2,300 people died each year as a result of work related exposure to chemicals. This does not reflect the current extent of death from occupational disease. In the near future, this ure may rise due to the expected increase in asbestos related deaths, a tragedy that for many decades has continued its macabre assault on working Australians, particularly through the Wittenoom disaster and the James Hardie disgrace. Australia has the highest incidence of asbestos related disease in the developed world. The incidence in Australia has been rising steeply since 1970, and it is estimated that the total number of asbestos related deaths will reach at least 40,000 and perhaps as many as 60,000 by 2020. More broadly, approximately 480,000 Australian employees experience a work related injury or illness each year. That lates to approximately 2.8 million Australians suffering from work related long-term health conditions. Each year there are around 140,000 compensated work related injuries resulting in an absence from work of one or more weeks. In comparison, there are over 13,500 road accidents involving casualties each year in Australia. That provides the context and background to the government's proposed changes to occupational health and safety arrangements. The Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Amendment Bill 2005 proposes to amend the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991. That act provides the legal basis for the protection of the health and safety of Commonwealth employees in departments, statutory authorities and government business enterprises. This amendment bill is the government's third attempt to introduce the provisions contained in this bill-namely, the removal of unions from workplace occupational health and safety institutions. As such, it is instructive to consider the legislative history of the preceding bills and the reasons for their prefig- vious rejection by the parliament. The Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991 is similar to its counterpart state and territory legislation, in that it follows the Robens model of occupational health and safety. The Robens model stems from the report of the committee on safety and welfare at work commissioned by the United Kingdom parliament in the early 1970s as a means of reducing the incidence of workplace death and injury. Essentially the approach by the Robens committee recommended greater selfregulation in the workplace through a collaborative approach between employers and transemployees. Importantly, the Robens model recognised the role unions play as employee representatives. As such, the principle of freedom of association was an important part of the Robens approach. The Robens model was largely followed in subsequent and similar inquiries conducted by both the states and the Commonwealth. Consequently, occupational health and safety committees have now become a familiar part of the industrial and workplace landscape across Australia. The effectiveness of the Robens approach was supported by the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission when it stated in November 2002: ... there is indirect but strong evidence that ployee participation, either direct or representaachieve tive, is an essential component of effective occuentry pational health and safety management. The government's first attempt to remove the role of unions in occupational health and safety matters was its Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Amendment Bill 2000. The 2000 bill lapsed with the prorogation of the parliament for the 2001 election. Before the lapse of the bill, the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee prepared a report on the bill's provisions. The essence of the Labor senators' report was threefold. Firstly, there was a rejection of a reduced role for unions, under the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991. Labor senators took the view that the government's position was driven by ‘ideological rhetoric associated with labour market opposition'. Moreover, there was evidence presented to the committee that where ‘unions back members of health and safety committees, the results will be lower workers compensation claims'. Secondly, there existed concern over the vagaries of the proposed safety management arrangements, especially given the ongoing success of the existing policy approach. Qualified support was given for a more flexible, dual civil and criminal system of occupational health and safety enforcement and compliance. Democrat senators took the view that that 2000 bill should be passed with amendments. Senator Murray's report stated: A key area of concern to us is the place of unions in the maintenance and advancement of workplace health and safety. Unions supplement the regulatory and inspectorial roles of State OH&S departments in an irreplaceable way. Unions as a whole sometimes get criticised as a result of the actions of some unionists in misusing the provisions of the various State health and safety Acts. emSuch unionists raise non-existent H&S issues to other industrial objectives, and misuse and search provisions under the pretext of H&S. Such behaviour needs to be addressed. However the way to deal with these abuses is not to clamp down on legitimate useful or effective union H&S activity. The government's second attempt was in June 2002 with the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Amendment (Employee Involvement and Compliance) Bill. That bill was referred to the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee, with Labor senators again recommending the amendment of the bill to remove provisions designed to reduce or remove union involvement in health and safety outcomes. Democrat senators stated that their position remained unchanged because the 2002 bill did not address the concerns raised in the 2000 Senate report. Some elements of that 2002 bill were subsequently enacted in the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Amendment (Employee Involvement and Compliance) Act 2004, which introduced a more flexible compliance regime. Senate amendments supported by Labor and the Democrats significantly diluted the original intent and key provisions of that 2002 bill. With that legislative summary, we come to this 2005 bill. Its proposed amendments are modelled on provisions unsuccessfully brought before the parliament in 2002, in particular as part of the employee involvement and compliance bill of that year. Let me refer to the bill's proposed provisions in respect of management arrangements. The bill proposes the introduction of management arrangements to replace occupational health and safety agreements traditionally developed through tripartite processes between unions, employers and employees. These management arrangements replace the requirement for government agencies to negotiate health and safety agreements with unions and employees to govern occupational health and safety matters. Current legislation provides for occupational health and safety committee meetings every three months, with committee meeting minutes kept for three years. These time frames will now be decided by the management arrangements. The bill also intends to remove all references to ‘unions' and replace them with ‘employee representatives', defined as either a ‘registered organisation' or a ‘workplace staff association'. The bill defines a workplace staff association as an: ... association of employees, a principal purpose of which is the protection and promotion of the employee's interests in matters concerning their employment. Additionally, the bill also proposes that employee representatives must be invited into the workplace by an employee. Furthermore, under the provisions of the bill, an employee must invite the employee representative to initiate any investigation into occupational health and safety matters. Under the current act a union is able to directly request Comcare to investigate a workplace. The bill also proposes that employee representative organisations request the right to be involved in occupational health and safety consultations by submission to the chief executive of Comcare. The Comcare chief executive may or may not then issue a certificate with whatever conditions are deemed necessary, with validity for a fixed period of 12 months. Finally, the bill also provides for employers to conduct the election of employee health and safety representatives, a role previously conducted by a union or a person specified by the soon to be abolished National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. In 2000 and 2002 the government failed to outline a sound analysis as to why the current provisions and policy approach of the act needed to be changed. In 2005 nothing has changed. In his second reading speech on 23 June, the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations stated: The Australian government believes strongly that safe and productive workplaces rely on a cooperative approach between employers and employees to identify and eliminate hazards that may cause injury or death. Obviously this cooperative approach does not extend to the inclusion of unions in public sector occupational health and safety matters and institutions. Occupational health and safety matters are best developed through the tripartite processes involving unions, employers and employees based on the long standing Robens model. This bill dismantles this tripartism and that approach, making it more difficult for employees to be adequately represented in these vital occupational health and safety matters. Academic evidence suggests a very strong link between union presence and involvement and improved occupational health and safety outcomes. In his July 2003 paper entitled Workplace arrangements for health and safety in the 21st century Professor David Walters outlined international research that clearly demonstrates that active and organised workers' representation is effective in ameliorating workplace hazards, that better standards are achieved in unionised workplaces than in non-unionised workplaces, that trained representatives stimulate and participate in workplace occupational health and safety structures and procedures and tackle new occupational health and safety issues, that work force participation in health and safety decisions is one of several factors related to lower claim rates and, finally, the empowerment of the work force was shown in Canadian studies to be one of the organisational reasons consistently related to lower injury rates. Empowerment in this situation includes the presence of unions, union support for worker members of joint health and safety committees and general worker participation in decision making. These conclusions are further supported by Johnstone, Quinlan and Walters in their 2004 report Statutory occupational health and safety workplace arrangements for the modern labour market. They quoted a range of international and Australian studies. They said: While there is considerable variation in the detail of these findings, taken collectively, they all support to the notion that joint arrangements, trade unions and trade union representation on health and safety at the workplace are associated with better health and safety outcomes than when employers manage occupational health and safety without representative worker participation. This bill proposes to remove all references to unions from the act. This effectively means that the role a trade union currently fulfils may be replaced by workplace staff associations. A workplace staff association may merely be a social club and may not fulfil the requirements mandated of a trade union, such as being democratic and independent. As such, by devolving responsibility from unions to employee representatives, as this bill proposes, strong occupational health and safety processes and outcomes will become increasingly difficult to enforce. The government intends to throw employees back on their own resources instead of using the occupational health and safety expertise built up by unions and their membership over many years. Employee representatives will lack the independent information and assistance currently provided by unions, while representatives themselves are likely to be less forthcoming in occupational health and safety negotiations with their employers. As an example, unions currently protect workers who may be afraid to raise certain occupational health and safety issues with their immediate supervisors. At present, workers can take such issues to the union and protect themselves from any personal repercussions. This will no longer be the case under the provisions of this bill. Furthermore, the proposal that a union member must seek permission from a public official-the Chief Executive of Comcarewho may or may not agree to involve a union representative in occupational health and safety matters is more likely than not to be a breach of the terms of ILO Convention 87, lend freedom of association, to which Australia became a party in 1973. Finally, the bill proposes that employers, not employees, control the election of employees' occupational health and safety representatives. This provision is a blatant attempt to ostracise unions from the occupational health and safety processes within Australian public sector workplaces. In the area of workplace relations the Howard government consistently talks about choice. It is ironic then that this bill seeks to curtail the choice of Australian employees working in the public sector to be represented by a union in occupational health and safety matters. This bill represents the government's third legislative attempt to deny Australian employees the basic and fundamental right to be represented by a union, if they so choose, in occupational health and safety matters. As such, it is driven by the government's extreme ideology rather than by any sense of sound public policy outcomes. Australian trade unions have a strong track record of protecting employees from unsafe work practices and places. It is clear that health and safety outcomes are dependent upon higher levels of worker participation and union support. Based on the research that I referred to earlier, removing the role of unions and replacing them with management driven processes will lead to less safe and less healthy workplaces. Unions have a legitimate role to play in the monitoring and enforcement of occupational health and safety matters in the public sector. Unions exist as a very important and necessary safeguard. I use the word ‘safeguard' because many occupational health and safety issues are already dealt with on a oneon-one basis in the workplace, between employees and/or between employees and their managers or supervisors. There are already many examples where occupational health and safety issues arise on a daily basis and employees, between themselves or with their managers, resolve them efficiently and expeditiously. In such cases, the involvement of unions as a third party is not a prerequisite and often does not occur because it is often not required or requested. There is no mandatory involvement of unions in such issues as the government would have us believe. We already have both union and non-union employees working cooperatively with management and achieving successful results in improving occupational health and safety standards, so the government's attempt to ostracise unions entirely from these matters is comprehensible only if one appreciates the government's ideological approach in these matters. The changes contained in this bill are so unashamedly anti-union, based as they are on that extreme ideological view, that neither an individual trade union nor the organised trade union movement has a role to play in occupational health and safety matters in the workplace. Mr Deputy Speaker, I simply put to you the illustration of the trade union movement coming to the assistance of the victims of James Hardie. Just ask yourself this simple question: where would the asbestosis and mesothelioma victims of James Hardie have been without the assistance of the trade union movement? I did not see employer associations come to the rescue of the victims of James Hardie. I did not see the Prime Minister, I did not see the Treasurer and I did not see the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. It fell to the organised trade union movement to come to the defence of fellow Australians to ensure some semblance of justice was done. If for no other reason, that in itself is justification of the legitimate role of the trade union movement in today's economic and social affairs-in particular, involvement in today's workplaces and especially when that relates to occupational health and safety. The government does not see it this way-a point that becomes clear when one examines this bill.
